sp.p: Faith 'tis hard to say which laboured most, he, or I, to make that match, but the knave did well; there it is (If you assist) I mean to lay the scene of your mirth tonight , for I am not yet fully revenged upon the rogue; for that I know him miserable is nothing, till he believe so too; wanton and I have laid the plot.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Do you hold correspondence?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Correspondence? I tell thee the plots we laid to draw him on would make a comedy.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the ladies stay dinner.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: And as we go I'll tell you all the story, and after dinner, be free from all engagements, as we promised thee; and follow but your directions, I'll warrant you mirth and a pretty wench.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Agreed, any thing that breeds mirth is welcome.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Not a word at the widows, let them go on quietly, and steal their wedding too.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I heard a bird sing, as if it were concluded amongst the couples.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: They have been long about it; my coz is a girl deserves more haste to her bed, he has arrived there by carrier's journeys.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
But that I hate wooing, by this good day, I like your
aunt so well and her humour she should scarce be thrown away upon paleface, that has sighed her into a wedding ring, and will but double her jointure.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why I, thus it should be, pray let us make them the seat of the war all dinner, and continue united and true among ourselves, than we may defy all foreign danger.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: And with full bowls let us crown this peace, and sing, wit, without war, no mirth doth bring.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Was she deaf to your report?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Yes, yes. The parson walks troubled up and down.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: And ugly, her Abigail, she had her say too?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: And do you walk here biting your nails: do you think I'll be satisfied with such a way of righting me?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: What wouldst have me do?

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Have you no gall? be abused and laughed at by a dull captain, that a strict muster would turn fool? you had wit, and could rail, when I offended you, and none so sudden, none so terrible, none so sure in his revenge, when I displease you.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Something I'll do.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Do it then, or I shall curse that e'er I saw you death, let the sign of my lady, an out of fashion whore, that has paid for sin, ever since yellow starch and wheel farthingales were cried down, let her abuse me, and say nothing? if this passes.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: As Christ bless me, but I did (Sweet heart:) and if it were not church livings are mortal, and they are always hitting me in the teeth with a man of your coat, she should find I am no church man within, nor Mr. parson but in my coat; come to dinner, and after dinner I'll do something.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: I shall do something will vex somebody .

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Will you please to come to dinner? the company stays.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Come, let's go in.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: No, I must walk a little to digest this breakfast, the guests else will wonder to see I am troubled.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Come, let this day pass in mirth, spite of mischief, for lucks sake.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: I'll follow you, and do what I can to be merry.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Why, he stands already.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Peace, let me alone, I'll make him jostle, like the miller's mare, and stand like the dun cow, till thou mayest milk him.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Pray break him of his miserableness, it is one of the chief exceptions I have against him; he reared a puppy once, till it was ten days old, with three hap 'Worth of milk, and then with his own dagger slew it, and made me dress it: blessed myself to see him eat
it, and he bid me beg the litter, and swore it was sweeter and wholesomer than sucking rabbits, or London pigs, which he called Belmen's issue.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Hark, he calls me, we must humour him a little, he'llParson calls within. Why sweet heart. rebel else.

div.head: Act. ii. scen. vii.
div.stage: Enter (At the windows) the widow and master careless, mistress pleasant and master Wild, captain, master sad, constant, jolly, secret, a table and knives ready for oysters.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: You re welcome all, but especially master jolly; no reply, with I thank your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I beseech you, sir, let us never be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: I shall endeavour, lady, and fail in nothing that is in myShe speaks to masterjolly power to disoblige you; for there is none more ambitious of your ill opinion than I.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I rejoice at it, for the less love, the better welcome still.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And as ever you had an ounce of love for the widow, be not friends among yourselves.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Aunt, though we were at strife when we were alone, yet now we unite like a politic state against the common enemy.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: The common enemy, what is that?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Women, and lovers in general.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Nay, than we have a party niece, claim; quickly, now is the time, according to the proverb; keep a thing seven years, and then if thou hast no use on't throw't away.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Agreed, let's challenge our servants; by the love they have professed, they cannot in honour refuse to join with us; and see where they come. —

div.stage: Enter sadd and constant, and meet secret, she whispers this to Sadd.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Be secret and grave, I'll warrant our design will take as we can wish.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Sweet mistress pleasant.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Servant sad.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: We are threatened to have a war waged against us, will you not second us?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: With these youths we'll do enough, madam.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I'll swear my servant gave hit for hit this morning, as if he had been a master in the noble science of wit.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Mine laid about him with spick and span new arguments, not like the same man, his old sayings and presidents laid by.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Thus armed, then, we'll stand and defy them.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
Where's your points, sure aunt, this should be your
wedding day, for you have taken the man for better for worse.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: No, nephew, this will not prove the day that we shall either give or take a ring.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Hang me, if I know you can go back again with your honour.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Or in justice refuse him liberty, that has served out his time; either marry him or provide for him, for he is maimed in your service.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why servant sad? you'll arm; my nephew has thrown the first dart at you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hast hit, hast hit?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, captain, 'twas too wide.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Too wide? Marry he's an ill marksman that shoots wider than a widow.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: We are both in one hole, captain; but I was loath to venture my opinion, lest her ladyship should think I was angry; for I have a good mind to fall upon the widow.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: You're a constant man, master jolly; you have been in that mind this twelvemonth's day.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You are in the right, madam; she has it to show under his hand, but she will not come in the list with him again; she threw him the last year.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Come, shall we eat oysters? Who's there? call for some wine, master jolly; you are not warm yet, pray be free, you are at home.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Your ladyship is merry.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: You do not take it ill, to have me assure you you are at home here?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Such another invitation (Though in jest) will take away master Sadd's stomach. Oysters net brought in yet.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: No, faith, Ned, though she should take him, it will not take away my stomach; my love is so fixed I may wish my wishes, but she shall never want them to wait upon hers.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: A traitor, bind him, has pulled down aside ; profess your love thus public?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: I by my faith, continue master sad, give it out you love, and call it a new love, a love never seen before, we'll all come to it as your friends.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Gentlemen, still I love; and if she to whom I thus sacrifice will not reward it, yet the worst malice can say, is, I was unfortunate and misfortunate; not false made me so.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: In what chapter shall we find this written, and what verse? you should preach with a method, master sad.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Gentlemen, if ever he spoke so much dangerous sense before (Either of love or reason) hang me.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Madam, my love is no news where you are; know, your scorn has made it public; and though it could gain no return from you; yet others have esteemed me for the faith and constancy I have paid here.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p:
Did not I foretell you of his love? I foresaw this danger,
shall I never live to see wit and love dwell together?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I am but a poor soldier, and yet never reached to the honour of being a lover; yet from my own observations, master sad, take a truth; 'tis a folly to believe any woman loves a man for being constant to another, they dissemble their hearts only; and hate a man in love worse than a wencher.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: And they have reason; for if they have the grace to be kind, he that loves the sex may be theirs.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: When your constant lover, if a woman have a mind to him, and be blessed with so much grace to discover it; he, out of the noble mistake of honour hates her for it, and tells it perchance, and preaches reason to her passion, and cries, miserable beauty, to be so unfortunate as to inhabit in so much frailty.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: This counsel makes her hate him more than she loved before; these are troubles, those that love are subject to, while we look on and laugh, to see both thus slaved while we are free.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: My prayers still shall be, lord deliver me from love.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Tis plague, pestilence, famine, sword, and sometimes sudden death.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Yet I love, I must love, I will love, and I do love.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: In the present tense.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: No more of this argument, for love's sake.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By any means, madam, give him leave to love, and you are resolved to walk tied up in your own arms, with your love as visible in your face, as your mistress's colours in your hat; that any porter at Charingcross may take you like a letter at the carriers, and having read the superscription, deliver master sad to the fair hands of mistress or my lady such a one, lying at the sign of the hard heart.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And she, if she has wit (As I believe she hath) will scarce pay the post for the packet.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Treason, how now niece, join with the enemy?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A health, Ned, what shall I call it? They give the captain wine.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To master sad, he needs it that avows himself a lover.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you have the advantage, the time, the place, the company; but we may meet when your wits shall not have such advantage as my love.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: No more of love, I am so sick on't.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: By your pardon, mistress, I must not leave love thus unguarded, I vow myself his follower.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Much good may love do him, give me a glass of wine here; will, let them keep company with the blind boy, give us his mother, and let them preach again; hear that will, he has good luck, persuades me 'tis an ugly sin to lie with a handsome woman.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
A pox upon my nurse, she frighted me so when I was young with storeys of the devil, I was almost fourteen ere I could prevail with reasons to unbind my reason, it was so slaved to faith and conscience; she made me believe wine was an evil spirit,
and fornication was like the whore of Babylon, a fine face, but a dragon under her petticoats; and that made me have a mind to peep under all I met since.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Fie, fie, for shame, do not talk so; are you not ashamed to glory in sin, as if variety of women were none.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Madam, we do not glory in fornication; and yet I thank God, I cannot live without a woman.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, does your ladyship think it a sin to lie with variety of handsome women? if it be, would I were the wickedest man in the company.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: You have been marked for an indifferent sinner; that way captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Who I? No faith, I was a fool, but and I were to begin again, I would not do as I have done, I kept one; but if ever I keep another, hang me; nor would I advise any friend of mine to do it.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Why, I am sure 'tis a provident and safe way; a man may always be provided and sound.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Fie upon this discourse.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Those considerations betrayed me, a pox; it is a dull sin to travel, like a carriers-horse, always one road.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Fie, captain, repent for shame, and marry.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Your ladyship would have said, marry, and repent; no, though it be not the greatest pleasure, yet it is better than marrying; for when I am weary of her, my unconstancy is termed virtue, and I shall be said to turn to grace. Beware of women, for better for worse; for our wicked nature, when her sport is lawful, cloys straight; therefore, rather than marry keep a wench.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Faith, he is in the right, for 'tis the same thing in number and kind; and then the sport is quickened, and made poignant with sin.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yet 'tis a fault, faith, and I'll persuade all my friends from it; especially here where any innovation is dangerous; 'twas the newness of the sin that made me suffer in the opinion of my friends; and I was condemned by all sorts of people; not that I sinned, but that I sinned no more.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why I, hadst thou been wicked in fashion, and privily lain with every body, their guilt would have made them protect thee; so that to be more wicked is to be innocent at least safe; a wicked world, lord help us.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
But being particular to her, and not in love, nor subject to it, taking an antidote every morning, before I venture into those infectious places where love beauty dwells; this enraged the maiden, beauties of the time, who thought it a prejudice to their beauties to see me careless, and securely pass by their conquering eyes; my name being found amongst none of those that decked their triumphs. But from this 'tis easy to be safe, for their pride will not let them love, nor my leisure me. Then the old ladies that pay for their pleasures; they, upon the news, beheld me with their natural frowns, despairing when their money could not prevail;
and hated me when they heard that I for my pleasure would pay as large as they.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Gentlemen, take warning; a fee from every man; for by this day, there's strange counsel in this confession.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Captain, you forget to pledge Mr. careless; here, will you not drink a cup of wine, who's there? Bring the oysters.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, madam, if you please.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Proceed, captain.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Fie, Mr. wild, are you not ashamed to encourage him to this filthy discourse.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A glass of wine then; and I'll drink to all the new married wives that grieve to think, at what rate their fathers purchase a little husband. These when they lie thirsting for the thing they paid so dear for.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: These, methinks, should be thy friends, and point thee out as a man for them.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, till the faithful nurse cries; alas, madam, he keeps such a one, he has enough at home; than she swells with envy and rage against us both, calls my mistress ugly, common, unsafe; and me, a weak secure fool.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: These are strange truths, madam.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Ay, ay, but these oysters are a better jest.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But she's abused that will let such reason tame her desire, and a fool in love's school; else she would not be ignorant that variety is such a friend to love, that he which rises a sunk coward from the lady's bed would find new fires at her maids; nor ever yet did the man want fire, if the woman would bring the fuel.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: For god's sake, leave this discourse.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: The captain has a mind we should eat no oysters.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Aunt, we came to be merry, and we will be merry, and you shall stay it out; proceed captain.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Fie captain, I'm ashamed to hear you talk thus: marry, than you will have a better opinion of women.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Marry! yes, this knowledge will invite me, it is a good encouragement, is it not think you? What is your opinion? were not these marriages made in heaven? By this good day, all the world is mad, and makes haste to be fooled, but we four: and I hope there's none of us believes there has any marriages been made in heaven, since Adam.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: By my faith, 'tis thought the devil gave the ring there to.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Nephew, I'll swear I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
Hold her, Ned, she goes not yet; there's a fourth kind of women that concerns her more than all the rest, ecce signum — she isHe points to Sadd.one of those who, clothed in purple, triumph over their dead husbands; these will be caught at first sight, and at first sight must be caught; 'tis a bird that must be shot flying, for they never sit; if a man delay they cool, and fall into considerations of jointure, and friend's opinion; in which time, if she hears thou keepest a wench, thou hadst better be a beggar in her opinion; for then her pride, it may be, would betray her to the vanity of setting up a proper
man; (As they call it) but for a wencher no argument prevails with your widow; for she believes they have spent too much that way, to be able to pay her due benevolence.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: As I live, I'll be gone if you speak one word more of this uncivil subject.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Captain, let me kiss thy cheek, for that widow; you understand this, widow? I say no more; here captain, here's to thee; as it goes down, a pox of care.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Jesus! Mr. jolly, have you no observations of the court, that are so affected with this of the town?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Faith, they say, there's good sport there, sometimes.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Mr. jolly is afraid to let us partake of his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: No faith, madam.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By this drink, if he stay till I have eaten a few more, I'll describe it.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: What should I say, 'tis certain the court is the bravest place in the kingdom, for sport, if it were well looked to, and the game preserved fair; but as 'tis, a man may sooner make a set in the strand. And it will never be better, whilst your divine lovers inhabit there.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let the King make me master of the game.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And admit us laiety-lovers.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: I would he would; for as 'tis, there's no hopes amongst the ladies; besides, 'tis such an example to see a King and Queen good, husband and wife, that to be kind will grow out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nay, that's not all, for the women grow malicious, because they are not courted; nay, they bred all the last mischiefs, and called the King's chastity a neglect of them.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Thou art in the right; an Edward, or a Harry, with seven Queens in buckram, that haught among the men, and stroked the women, are the monarchs they wish to bow to; they love no tame princes, but lions in the forest.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, and those were properly called the fathers of their people, that were indeed akin to their nobility; now they wear out their youth and beauty, without hope of a monumental ballad, or trophy of a lie-bell that shall hereafter point at such a lord, and cry that is the royal son of such a one.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: And these were the ways that made them powerful at home; for the city is a kind of tame beast; you may lead her by the horns any whither, if you but tickle them in the ear sometimes. Queen Bess, of famous memory, had the trick on't; and I have heard them say, in eighty eighty, ere I was born, as well I can remember, she road to Tilbury on that bonny beast, the mayor.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I would I might counsel him; I'd so reform the court.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Never too soon; for now, when a stranger comes in, and spies a covey of a beauty's, would make a falconer unhood, before he can draw his leash he is warned that's a markt partridge; and that, and every he, has by their example a particular she.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
By this light, the six fair maids stand like the working-days in the almanac; one with a scored upon her breast, that is
as much to say, I belong to such a lord; the next with b for an elder brother; c for such a knight; d possessed with melancholy, and at her breast you may knock an hour ere you get an answer, and then she'll tell you there's no lodging there; she has a constant fellow courtier that has taken up all her heart to his own use: in short, all are disposed of, but the good mother; and she comes in like the sabbath, at the weeks end; and I warrant her make any one rest that comes at her.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I marry; but if she were like the Jews sabbath, it were somewhat; but this looks like a broken commandment, that has had more work done upon her, than all the week besides.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And what think you, is not this finely carried? you that are about the King, counsel him, if he will have his sport fair, he must let the game be free, as it has been in former ages; then a stranger that has wit, good means, and handsome clothes, no sooner enters the privy chamber, and beat about with three graceful legs, but he spring a mistress that danced as well as he, sung better, as free as fair; those at first sight could speak, for wit is always acquainted: these fools must be akin ere they can speak; and now the friends make the bargain, and they go to bed ere they know why.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Faith, he's in the right, you shall have a buzzard now hover and beat after a pretty wench, till she is so weary of him she's forced to take her bed for covert, and find less danger in being trussed then in flying.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And what becomes of all this pother, after he has made them sport for one night, to see him touse the quarry, he carries her into the country, and there they two fly at one another till they are weary.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And all this mischief comes of love and constancy; we shall never see better days till there be an act of parliament against it; enjoining husband not to till their wives, but change and lay them fallow.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: A pox, the women will never consent to it; they'll be tilled to death first.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Gentlemen, you are very bold with the sex.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Faith, madam, it is our care of them; why you see they are married at fourteen, yield a crop and a half, and then die, 'tis merely their love that destroy 'em; for if they get a good husbandman, the poor things yield their very hearts.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And do you blame their loves, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: No, not their love, but their discretion; let them love, and do, a god's name; but let them do with discretion.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But how will you amend this?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Instead of two beds and a physician; I'd have the state prescribe two wives and a mistress.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ho! it will never be granted; the state is made up of old men, and they find work enough with one.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p:
We will petition the lower house, there are young men, and (If it were but to be factious) would pass it, if they thought
the upper house would cross it; besides, they ought to do it, death! they provide against cutting down old trees, and preserving highways and post-horses, and let pretty wenches run to decay?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why may it not come within the statute of depopulation? As I live, the state ought to take care of those pretty creatures; be you judge, madam; is't not a sad sight to see a rich young beauty, with all her innocence and blossoms on, subject to some rough rude fellow, that ploughs her; and esteems and uses her as a chattel, till she is so lean, a man may find as good grass upon the common, where it may be she'll sit coughing with sunk eyes, so weak that a boy (With a dog) that can but whistle, may keep a score of them?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: You are strangely charitable to our sex, on a sudden.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I know not what they are; but for my part, I'll be a traitor ere I'll look on, and see beauty go thus to wrack; it is enough, custom has made us suffer them to be enclosed; I am sure, they were created common, and for the use of man, and not intended to be subject to jealousy and choler, or to be bought or sold, or let for term of lives or years, as they are now, or else sold at outcries; oh! yes; who'll give most take her.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why do not some of you, excellent men, marry, and mend all these errors, by your good example?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Because we want fortunes, to buy rich wives, or keep poor ones, and be loath to get beggars, or whores, as well as I love 'em.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, are all their children so that have no fortune think you?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: No, not all; I have heard of Whittington and his cat, and others, that have made fortunes by strange means; but I scarce believe my son would rise from hope, a half penny, and a lambskin; and the wenches commonly having more wit and beauty then money, foreseeing small portions, grow sad, and read romances, till their wit spy some unfortunate merit like their own, without money too, and they two sigh after one another, till they grow mysterious in colours, and become a proverb for their constancy; and when their love has worn out the cause, marry in the end a new couple, then grown ashamed of the knowledge they so long hunted, at length part, by consent, and vanish into Abigail and governor.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Well gentlemen, excuse me for this one time; and if ever I invite you to dinner again, punish me with such another discourse, in the mean time let's go in and dine, meat stays for us.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Faith madam, we were resolved to be merry; we have not met these three years till today, and at the bear we meant to have dined; and since your ladyship would have our company, you must pardon our humour; here mistress sad, here's the widow's health to you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Nephew, how do you dispose of yourself this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: We have a design we must pursue, which will rid you of all this troublesome company; and we'll make no excuse, because you peeped into our privacies today.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Your humble servant, ladies; gentlemen, we'll leave you to pursue your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Farewell widow, mayest thou live unmarried till thou runnest away with thyself.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No, no, when that day comes, command the humblest of your servants.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Farewell aunt; sweet mistress pleasant, I wish you good fortune.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Farewell, farewell gentlemen; niece, now if we could be rid of these troublesome lovers too, we would go see a play.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Rid of them? Why, they are but now in season; as I live,She speaks aside.I would do as little to give mine content as any she in town, and yet I do not grudge him the happiness of carrying me to a play.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Ay, but the world will talk, because they pretend; and than we shall be sure to meet my nephew there, and his wild company, and they will laugh to see us together.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Who will you have? Tim the butler, or formal your gentleman usher? I would take Philip the foreman of the shop as soon.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Let's mask ourselves, and take secret, and go alone by water.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Yes, and follow her like one of my ants of the suburbs; it is a good way to know what you may yield in a market; for I'll undertake, there are those shall bid for you before the play will be done.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: As I live, madam, mistress pleasant is in the right; I had such a kindness offered me once, and I came to a price with him in knavery; and hang me, if the rogue was not putting the earnest of his affection into my hand.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Let's go to the glass-house then.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I'll go to a play with my servant, and so shall you; hang opinion, and we'll go to the glass-house afterwards; it is too hot to sup early.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: Pray madam go, they say 'tis a fine play, and a knight writ it.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Pray let secret prevail, I'll propose it to the lovers; in the mean time go you, and bid the coachman make ready the coach.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: Alas, madam, he's sick, poor fellow, and gone to bed, he could not wait at dinner.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Sick?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, see how all things work for the young men, either their coach, or a foot; Mr. constant, what think you of seeing a play this afternoon? is it not too hot to venture, this infectious time?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Fie, madam, there's no danger, the bill decreased twenty last week.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: I swear, they say, 'tis a very good play today.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Shall we go, niece?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Faith 'tis hot, and there's nobody but we.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Does that hinder? pray madam, grudge us not the favour of venturing yourself in our company.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Come, leave this ceremony, I'll go in, and put on my mask; secret shall bring you yours;

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: No, I'll go, and put it on within.

div.head: Act. iii. Scen. ii.
div.stage: Enter Wild, careless, captain and jolly.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By this day, you have nettled the widow.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The captain neglected his dinner for his mirth, as if he had forgotten to eat.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: When did he oversee his drinking so?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Gentlemen, still it is my fortune to make your worships merry.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: As I live, captain, I subscribe, and am content to hold my wit as tenant to thee; and tonight I'll invite you to supper, where it shall not be lawful to speak till thou has victualled thy man of war.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Shall's be merry? what shall we have?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Half a score dishes of meat, choose them yourself.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Provide me then the chines fried, and the salmon calvered, a carp, and black sauce, red-deer in the blood, and an assembly of woodcocks, and jack-snipes, so fat you would think they had their winding sheets on; and upon these, as their pages, let me have wait your Sussex wheat-ear, with a feather in his cap; over all which let our countryman, general chine of beef, command: I hate your French pottage, that looks as the cook maid had more hand in it then the cook.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll promise you all this.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And let me alone to cook the fish.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You cook it? No, no, I left an honest fellow in town, when I went into Italy, signior Ricardo Ligones, one of the ancient house of the Armenian ambassadors; if he be alive he shall be our cook.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Is he so excellent at it?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Excellent? You shall try, you shall try; why, I tell you, I saw him once dress a shooing-horn, and a joiner's apron, that the company left pheasant for it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A shooing-horn?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, a shooing-horn; marry, there was garlic in the sauce.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Is this all you would have?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: This, and a bird of paradise, to entertain the rest of the night, and let me alone to cook her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A bird of paradise, what's that?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A girl of fifteen, smooth as satin, white as her Sunday apron, plump, and of the first down: I'll take her with her guts in her belly, and warm her with a country dance or two, then pluck her, and lay her dry betwixt a couple of sheets; there pour into her so much oil of wit as will make her turn to a man, and stick into her heart three corns of whole love, to make her taste of what she is doing, then having strewed a man all over her, shut the door, and leave us, we'll work ourselves into such a sauce as you can never surfeit on, so poignant and yet no hogough; take heed of a hogo, your onion and woman make the worst sauce; this shook together by an English cook (For your French seasoning spoils many a woman) and there's a dish for a King.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: For the first part, I'll undertake.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But this for supper; captain. No more of this now; this afternoon, as you are true to the pettycoat, observe your instructions, and meet at Ned's house in the evening.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We will not fail.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I must write to wanton, to know how things stand at home, and to acquaint her how we have thrived with the old lady today.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Whither will you go to write?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: To thy house, 'tis hard by, there's the fleece.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Do, and in the mean time I'll go home and dispatch a little business, and meet you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Make haste then.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Where shall I meet you?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Whither shall we go till it be time to attend the design.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let's go to court for an hour.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Do, I'll meet you at the Queen's side.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, prithee, we are the mounsieurs new come over; and if we go fine they will laugh at us, and think we believe ourselves so; if not, than they will abuse our clothes, and swear we went into France only to have our cloaks cut shorter.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Will you go see a play?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Do, and thither I'll come to you, if it be none of our gentlemen poets, that excuse their writings with a prologue that professes they are no scholars.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: On my word this is held the best penned of the time, and he has writ a very good play; by this day, it was extremely applauded.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Does he write plays by the day; indeed a man would ha' judged him a labouring poet.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: A labouring poet? by this hand he's a knight; upon my recommendation venture to see it; hang me if you be not extremely well satisfied.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A knight and write plays? it may be, but 'tis strange to us; so they say there are other gentlemen poets without land or Latin; this was not ordinary; prithee when was he knighted?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: In the North; the last great knighting, when 'twas god's great mercy we were not all knights.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll swear, they say, there are poets that have more men in liveries, than books in their studies.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And what think you, gentlemen, are not these things to start a man? I believe 'tis the first time you have found them lie at the sign of the page, footmen and gilded coaches; they were wont to lodge at the thin cloak, they and their muses made up the family; and thence sent scenes to their patrons, like boys in at windows, and one would return with a doublet, another with a pair of breeches, a third with a little ready money; which, together with their credit with a company, in three terms you rarely saw a poet repaired.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: This truth nobody denies.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Prithee let us resolve what we shall do, lest we meet with some of them: for it seems they swarm, and I fear nothing like a dedication, though it be but of himself; for I must hear him say more than either I deserve or he believes; I hate that in a poet, they must be dull, or all upon all subjects; so that they can oblige none but their muse.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: I perceive by this you will not see the play; what think you of going to Sims, to bowls, till I come?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes, if you will go to see that comedy; but there is no reason we should pay for our coming in, and act too; like some whose interest in the timber robs them of their reason, and they run as if they had stolen a bias.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Resolve what you will do, I am contented.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let's go walk in the spring-garden.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll do it for company, but I had as live be rid in the horse-market, as walk in that fools fair; where neither wit nor money is, nor sure to take up a wench; there's none but honest women.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A pox on't, what should we do there? let's go and cross the field to pikes, her kitchen is cool winter and summer.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I like that motion well, but we have no time, and I hate to do that business by half; after supper, if you will, we'll go and make a night on't.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well, I must go write, therefore resolve of somewhat; shall I propose an indifferent place where 'tis probable we shall all meet.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Go you before to the devil, and I'll make haste after.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Agreed, we shall be sure of good wine there and in Fresco, for he is never without patent snow.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Patent snow, what doth that project hold?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Yes, faith, and now there is a commission appointed for toasts against the next winter.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Marry, they are wise, and foresaw the parliament, and were resolved their monopolies should be no grievance to the people.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Farewell, you will be sure to meet.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

div.head: Act. iii. Scen. iii.
div.stage: Enter wanton and her maid, with her lap full of things.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: Bid them ply him close and flatter him, and rail upon the old lady and the captain; and, do you hear, give him some hints to begin the story of his life, do it handsomely, and you shall see how the sack will clip his tongue.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I warrant you, I'll fit him.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: When he is in his discourse, leave him and come down into the parlour, and steal away his box with the false rings that stands by his bedside; I have all his little plate here already.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Make you haste, I'll warrant you I'll dress him.

div.head: Act. iii. Scen. iv.
div.stage: Enter the captain with a letter in his hand, and his boy to him with a candle, his going to write the superscription.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, the lady Loveall passed by even now.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The lady Loveall? which way went she.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To the rich lady the widow, where your worship dined.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Tis no matter; here, carry this letter, and bring an answer to the devil quickly; and tell her we'll stay there till the time be fit for the design.

div.head: Act. iii. Scen. v.
div.stage: Enter careless, Wild, and a drawer, at the devil.

sp.speaker: Careless.
sp.p: Jack, how goes the world? Bring us some bottles of the best wine.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: You shall, sir; your worship is welcome into England.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why look you, who says a drawer can say nothing, but anon, anon, sir? score a quart of sack in the half-moon.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Your worship is merry; but I'll fetch you that, sir, shall speak Greek, and make your worship prophecy, you drank none such in your journey.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Do it then, and make a hole in this angel thou mayst creep through; who is't that peeps, a fiddler? Bring him by theGives him an angel.ears.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: A tailor, an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A tailor? hast thou a stout faith?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I have had, an't like your worship; but now I am in despair.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Why then thou art damned; go, go home, and throw thyself into thine own hell, it is the next way to the other.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I hope your worship is not displeased.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What dost do here? A tailor without faith, dost come to take measure of ours?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: No, I come to speak with one master jolly, a courtier, a very fine spoken gentleman, and a just compter, but one of the worst paymasters in the world.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: As thou lovest me, let's keep him here till he comes, and make him valiant with sack that he may urge him till he beatsAside.him; we shall have the sport, and be revenged upon the rogue for dunning a gentleman in a tavern.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I'll charge him: here drink, poor fellow, and stay in the next room till he comes.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I thank your worship, but I am fasting; and if it please your worship to call for a dozen of manchets that I may eat a crust first, then I'll make bold with a glass of your sack.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Here, here, drink in the mean time, fetch him some bread.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Will your worship have me drink all this vessel of sack?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes, yes, off with't, 'twill do you no harm. The Taylor drinks.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why do you not take some order with that jolly to make him pay thee?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I have petitioned him often, but can do no good.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A pox upon him, petition him, his heart is hardened to ill, threaten to arrest him; nothing but sergeant can touch his conscience.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Truly, gentlemen, I have reason to be angry, for he uses me ill, when I ask him for my money. Jolly speaks within.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Where is master wild, and master careless?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I hear his voice.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Let the coach stay. How now, who would he speak with?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Do not you know?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Yes, and be you judge if the rogue does not suffer deservedly; I have bid him any time this twelvemonth but send his wife, and I'll pay her, and the rogue replies, nobody shall lie with his wife but himself.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay, if you be such a one.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: No more they shall not, I am but a poor man.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: By this hand, he's drunk.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Nay then, I arrest you in mine own name at his majesty's suit.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: As I live, thou shalt not beat him.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Beat him? I'll kiss him, I'll pay him, and carry him about with me, and be at the charge of sack to keep him in the humour.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Help, rescue, I'll have his body, no bail shall serve. He hugs the quart pot.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Sir, yonder is a gentleman would speak with you; I do not like his followers.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: What are they, bailiffs?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Little better.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Send him up alone, and stand you ready at the stairs feet.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: It is the scrivener at the corner, pick a quarrel with him for coming into our company; the drawers will be armed behind them, and we will so rout the rascals; take your swords, and let him sleep.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What scrivener?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Cropp the brownist, he that the ballad was made on.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What ballad?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Have not you heard of the scrivener's wife that brought the blackamoor from the holy land, and made him a brownist; and in pure charity lay with him, and was delivered of a magpie; a pied prophet; which when the elect saw, they prophesied, if it lived, 'twould prove a great enemy to their sect; for the midwife cried out, 'twas born a Bishop, with tippet and white-sleeves; at which the zealous mother cried, down with the idol; so the midwife and she in pure devotion killed it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Killed it? what became of them?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Why, they were taken and condemned, and suffered under a catholic sheriff, that afflicted them with the litany all the way from Newgate to the gallows, which in roguery he made to be set up altarwise too, and hanged them without a psalm.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But how took they that breach of privilege?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: I know not, Gregory turned them off, and so they descended, and became brown-martyrs.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And is the husband at door now?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Yes, yes, but he's married again to a rich widow at Wapping, a wench of another temper, one that you cannot please better than by abusing him; I always pick quarrels with him, that she may reconcile us, the peace is always worth a dinner, at least. Hark, I hear him. — save you Mr. Cropp, you are come in the nick to pledge a health.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: No, sir, I have other business, shall I be paid my money, or no?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Yes. Jolly drinks.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: You asked whether you should be paid your money, or no, and I said, yes.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Pray, sir, be plain.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And be you so, sir; how durst you come into this room, and company, without leave?

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Sir, I have come into good lords company, ere now.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
It may be so, but you shall either fall upon your knees,
and pledge this health, or you come no more into lords companies, no, by these hilts.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: 'Tis idolatry; do, martyr me, I will not kneel, nor joinThey tug him and make him kneel.in sin with the wicked.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Either kneel, or I'll tear thy cloak, which by the age and looks, may be that which was writ for in the time of the primitive church.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Pay me, and I'll wear a better; it would be honestlier done, than to abuse this, and profane the text; a text that shows your Bishops in those days wore no lawn-sleeves; and you may be ashamed to protect him that will not pay his debts; the cries of the widow will come against you for it.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Remember, sirrah, the dinners and suppers, fat venison and good words, I was fain to give you, christening your children still, by the way of brokage; count that charge, and how often I have kept you from fining for sheriff, and thou art in my debt; then I am damned for speaking well of thee so often against my conscience, which you never consider.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: I am an honest man, sir.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Then ushering your wife, and mistress ugly her daughter, to plays and masques at court; you think these courtesies deserve nothing in the hundred; 'tis true, they made room for themselves with their dagger elbows; and when spider your daughter laid about her with her breath, the devil would not have sat near her.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: You did not borrow my money with this language.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: No, sirrah; then I was fain to flatter you, and endure the familiarity of your family, and hear (Nay fain sometimes to join in) the lying praises of the holy sister that expired at Tyburn.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Do, abuse her, and be cursed; 'tis well known she died aHe offers to go, and jolly stays him. martyr; and her blood will be upon some of you, 'tis her orphan's money I require; and this is the last time I'll ask it, I'll find a way to get it.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Art serious? By that light, I'll consent, and take it for an infinite obligation if thou wilt teach the rest of my creditors that trick; 'twill save me a world of labour; for, hang me if I know how to do't.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Well, sir, since I see your resolution, I shall make it my business.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Prithee, let's be rid of this fool.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Fool? let him pay the fool his money, and he'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: No, sir, not a farthing; 'twas my business to borrow it, and it shall be yours to get it in again; nay, by this hand, I'll be feasted too, and have good words; nay, thou shalt lend me more ere thou gettest this again.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: I'll lay my action upon you.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Your action you rogue, lay two. They kick him and thrust him out the room.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Lay three for battery; what have we here? A she creditor too? who would she speak with?

div.stage: Enter faithful, Wild and careless return and meet her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: She looks as if she had trusted in her time.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Would you speak with any here, old gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: My business is to Mr. jolly.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: From yourself, or are you but a messenger?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: My business, sir, is from a lady.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: From a lady? from what lady, pray? Why so coy?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: From a lady in the town.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Hoh! hoh! from a lady in the town; is it possible I should have guessed you came from a lady in the suburbs, or some country-madam, by your riding face?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: I think we have routed the rascals. Faithful? what makes thy gravity in a tavern?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Sport, it seems, for your saucy companions.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Ho, ho, Mull, ho; no fury, faithful.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: 'Tis well, sir; my lady presents her service to you, and hath sent you a letter, there's my business.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Prithee, who is her lady?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: The lady Loveall.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: O, o, does she serve that old lady? God help her.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: God help her: pray for yourself, sir, my lady scorns your prayers.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Faithful, come hither; prithee is thy lady drunk?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Drunk, sir?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Ay, drunk, or mad, she'd never writ this else; she requires me, here, to send back by you the pearl she gave me this morning; which sure she'd never do if she were sober; for you know, I earned them hard.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: I know? What do I know? you will not defame my lady, will you?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By no means, this is by way of counsel; fie, give a thing, and take a thing; if he did not perform, he shall come at night, and pay his scores.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: 'Tis well, sir; is this your return for my lady's favours? shall I have the pearl, sir?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: No; and tell her 'tis the opinion of us all, he that opens her stinking oyster is worthy of the pearl.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: You are a foul-mouthed fellow, sirrah; and I shall live to see you load a gallows, when my lady shall find the way to her own again.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: If she miss, there are divers can direct her, you know; adieu, faithful, do you hear? steal privately down by the backdoor, lest some knavish boy spy thee, and call thine age, bawd.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Prithee, who is this thing?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p:
'Tis my lady's waiting-woman, her bawd, her she confessor, herself at second hand; her beginning was simple and below stairs, till her lady finding her to be a likely promising bawd; secret
as the key at her girdle, obedient as her thoughts, those virtues raised her from the flat petticoat, and kercher, to the gorget and bum-roll; and I remember 'twas good; sport at first, to see the wench perplexed with her metamorphosis; she since has been in love with all the family, and now sighs after the Levite; and if he forsake her too, I prophesy, a waiting-woman's curse will fall upon her, to die old, despised, poor, and out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why do you not hang out a painted cloth? and take two pence a piece, and let in all the tame fools at door, those sons of wonder that now gape, and think you mad.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter what they think, madness is proper here; are not taverns Bacchus his temples, the place of madness, does not the sign of madness hang out at the door?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: While we within possess our joys and cups, as full of pleasure as weeping Niobe's afflicted eyes were swelled with grief and tears; blessing on the cause that made our joys thus complete; for see Plutus in our pockets, Mars by our sides, Bacchus in our head, self-love in our hearts, and change of virgins in our arms, beauties whose eyes and hearts speak love and welcome; no rigid thinkers, no niggard beauties that maliciously rake up their fire in green sickness to preserve a spark that shall flame only in some dull day of marriage; let such swear and forswear, till (Of the whole parish) they love each other least, whilst we wisely set out our cobwebs in the most perspicuous places to catch these foolish flies.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: He's in the right; dost think we retreated hither to beat a bargain for a score of sheep, or dispute the legality of votes, and weigh the power of prerogative and parliament, and club for concluding sack, or read the fathers here, till we grow costive, like those that have worn their suffering elbows bare, to find a knowledge to perplex 'em? A pox on such brain-breaking thoughts; avoid them, and take with me into thy hand a glass of eternal sack, and prophesy the restauration of senses, and the fall of a lover from grace, which our dear friend, Mr. jolly, will prove to whom the lady Loveall (By faithful lately departed) sent for the pearl you wot of.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But, I hope, he had the grace to keep them.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: No, no; I'm a fool, I.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Was not my boy here?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: No, we saw him not.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A pox of the rogue, he's grown so lazy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Your boy is come in just now, and called for the key of the backdoor, there's women with him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Oh! that's well, 'tis wanton; I sent for her, to laugh over the story of the old lady and her pearl; where have you been all this while, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I could overtake the coach, sir, no sooner.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The coach? what coach?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The lady Love-all's.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The lady Love-all's? why what had you to do with her coach?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I went to give her the letter your worship sent her.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The letter? what letter?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That your worship gave me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That I writ, at Ned's house, to wanton?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The letter you gave me, sir, was directed to the lady Loveall, and she stormed like a madwoman at the reading of it.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why, thou wilt not beat the boy for thy own fault? what letter was it?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Twas enough, only a relation of the pearl, wherein she finds herself sufficiently abused to wanton.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Now, gentlemen, you have two to laugh at.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A pox of fooling, let's resolve what to do, there's no denying, for she has all the particulars under my hand.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You must resolve of something, for she's coming, and stayed only till the backdoor was opened.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How did she know I was here?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Your worship bade me tell her, you would stay here for her.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: How came this mistake?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, the devil ought us a shame it seems. You know I went home to give wanton an account how we advanced in our design; and when I was writing the superscription, I remember the boy came in and told me the lady Loveall passed by.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: And so, it seems, you in pure mistake directed your letter to her.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well, resolve what you'll do with her, when she comes.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Faith, bear it like men, 'tis but an old lady lost; let's resolve to defy her, we are sure of our pearl; but lest we prolong the war, take the first occasion you can all to avoid the room; when she's alone, I'll try whether she'll listen to a composition.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Have you no friends in the close committee?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, yes, I am an Essex man.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Then get some of them to move, it may be voted no letter.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Ay, i; and after 'tis voted no letter, then vote it false, scandalous and illegal, and that is in it; they have a precedent for it in the Danish packet, which they took from a foolish fellow, who presuming upon the law of nations, came upon an embassy to the King without an order, or pass from both houses.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hark, I hear her coming.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir, I received a letter, but by what accident I know not; for I believe it was not intended me, though the contents concern me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Madam, 'tis too late to deny it; is it peace or war you bring? without dispute, if war, I hang out my defiance; if peace, I yield my weapon into your hands.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
Are you all unworthy? your whole sex falsehood? is it not possible to oblige a man to be loyal? this is such a treachery no age can match; apply yourself with youth and wit to gain a lady's love and friendship only to betray it? was it not enough
you commanded my fortune, but you must wrack my honour too, and instead of being grateful for that charity which still assisted your wants, strive to pay men with injuries, and attempt to make the world believe I pay to lose my fame? and then make me theHe smiles.scorned subject of your whore's mirth; base and unworthy, do you smile, false one? I shall find a time for you too, and my vengeance shall find you all.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Yea, sir; and you that had such a ready wit to proclaim my lady, whore and me bawd, I hope to see you load a gallows for it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Once again, is it peace or war?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Peace? I'll have thy blood first, dog; where's my pearl? — you ought to right me, sir, in this particular; it was to you IShe speaks to Wild.sent them.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Madam, I sent not for them.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No more words; I have them, I earned them, and you paid them.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: You are a foul-mouthed fellow, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Peace, wench, I scorn their slander, it cannot shake my honour; 'tis too weighty and too fixed for their calumny.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: I'll be sworn for my part on't, I think it is a great honour; I am sure I had as much as I could carry away in ten nights, and yet there was no miss on't.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You? I think so; there's no mark of my work, you see, and yet I came after thee, and brought away loads would have sunk a sedan-man.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By this relation she should be a woman of a great fame.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let that consideration, with her condition, and her age, move some reverence, at least to what she was; madam, I am sorry I cannot serve you in this particular.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I see all your mean baseness, pursue your scorn; come, let's go, wench, I shall find some to right my fame; and though I have lost my opinion, I have gained a knowledge how to distinguish of love hereafter; and I shall scorn you and all your sex, that have not soul enough to value a noble friendship.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Pray, madam, let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: We'll have no whispering; I said it, and I'll maintain it with my sword.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Sir, there's one without would speak with you?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: With me?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: No, sir, with master wild.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Madam, I'll wait upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Madam, I know my company is displeasing to you, therefore I'll take my leave; drawer, show me another room? The Capt. makes a turn or two, they look at each other, then be goes out.

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: O faithful, faithful; I am most miserably abused, and can find no way to my revenge.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Madam, I'll give them ratsbane, and speedily too, ere they can tell; for that rascal the captain has a tongue else, will proclaim you, and undo your fame for ever.

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: Ay, ay, my fame, my fame, faithful; and if it were not for mine honour, (Which I have kept unstained to this minute) I would not care.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: This it is; you will still set your affection upon every young thing; I could but tell you on't.

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: Who could have suspected they would have been so false in their loves to me that have been so faithful to them. — honest friend, where is master wild?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: The other gentlemen carried him away with them?

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: Are they all gone then?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Yes, by this hand; these gentlemen are quickly satisfied; what an ugly whore they have got! how she states it! Aside.

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: Come, let's go wench. She offers to go.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Mistress, who pays the reckoning?

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: What says he?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: He asks me, who pays the reckoning?

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: Who pays the reckoning? why, what have we to do with the reckoning?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Shut the door, Dick, we'll have the reckoning before you go.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Why, goodman saucebox, you will not make my lady pay for their reckoning, will you?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: My lady? A pox of her title, she'd need of something to make her pass.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: What do you say, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: I say, the gentlemen paid well for their sport; and I know no reason why we should lose our reckoning.

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: What do you take me for, my friend?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: In troth, I take you for nothing; but I would be loath to take you for that use I think they made shift with you for.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Madam, this is that rascally captain's plot.

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: Patience, Patience, o for a bite at the slave's heart. Friend, mistake me not, my name is Loveall, a lady; send one along with me and you shall have your money.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: You must pardon me, madam, I am but a servant; if you be a lady pray sit in an inner room, and send home your woman for the money; the sum is six pounds, and be pleased to remember the waiters.

sp.speaker: Loveall.
sp.p: Go faithful, go fetch the money; o revenge, revenge: shall I lose my honour, and have no revenge.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. i.
div.stage: Enter wanton, captain, careless and Wild.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p:
By all that a longing bride hopes for, which I am not, I am better pleased with this revenge then mine own plot, which takes as I could wish; I have so anointed my high priests with sack, that he would have confuted Baal's priest; and now he does
so slumber in his ale, and calls to bed already, swears the sun is set.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Faith, wench, her abusing of me made me leave her for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes, faith, they have treated her upsey whore lain with her, told, and then pawned her.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Yes, yes, you are fine things; I wonder women, can endure you; for me, I expect you worse, and am armed for't.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith let's send and release her, the jest is gone far enough; as I live, I pity her.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: Pity her? hang her, and rid the country of her, she is a thing wears out her limbs as fast as her clothes, one that never goes to bed at all, nor sleeps in a whole skin, but is taken to pieces like a motion, as if she were too long; she should be hanged for offering to be a whore.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: As I live, she is in the right; I peeped once to see what she did before she went to bed; by this light, her maids were dissecting her; and when they had done, they brought some of her to bed, and the rest they either pined or hung up, and so she lay dismembered till morning; in which time, her chamber was strewed all over, like an anatomy school.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: And when she travels anywhere she is transported with as great a care, and fear of spoiling, as a juggler's motion, when he removes from fair to fair.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: She is a right broken gamester, who, though she lacks wherewithal to play, yet loves to be looking on.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: He is awake, and calls for you impatiently, he would fain be in bed, the company is all gone.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: Are you instructed?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Let me alone, I'll warrant you for my part.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: Farewell then, you are all ready; who plays master Constable?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ay, i; and Ned jolly the sumner.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Farewell, farewell then.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It is a delicate wench.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: She has excellent flesh, and a fine face; by this light, weThey whisper this.must depose the captain from his reign here.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I like her shrewdly; I hate a wench that is all whore and no company; this is a comedy all day, and a fair at night.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I hope to exalt the parson's horn here.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And what think you? is it not a sweet sin, this lying with another man's wife? Wanton above.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Is jolly come

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No, but he'll be here instantly.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Is he a-bed ?

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Yes, yes, and he sleeps as if he had been put to bed by his sexton, with dust to dust, and ashes to ashes.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And we'll wake him with that shall be as terrible to him as the latter day.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Let him sleep a while that he may be fresh, else the jest is spoiled; for it is his sense of his disgrace must work my ends.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll go home then, and get supper ready, and expect you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Do, our scene lies here; who's there, jolly?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Are you fitted?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Yes, I have got the Blackfriars music; I was fain to stay till the last act; and who do you think I saw there?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Guess.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Prithee, I cannot guess.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Your aunt and mistress pleasant, and trusty secret.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What man?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: The lovers only, so close in a box!

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: It will be a match, and there's an end; prithee let them go to't; what is't to us, let's mind our business now, and think on them hereafter.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: A pox upon them for a couple of stauk-hounds; have they killed at last? Why, this is fool's fortune; it would be long enough ere one that has wit got such a wife.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No more of this now; have you borrowed the watchmen's coats?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Yes, and bills, beards, and constable's staff, and lantern; and let me alone to fit him, for the summer; but when this is done I expect my fee, a tithe night at least; wanton, I will lie with thee for thy roguery; what are you dumb, you will not refuse me, I hope?

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Not, if I thought thou desiredst it; but I hate to have it desired indifferently, and but so so done neither when 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: I hope you will not disgrace my work, will you?

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Faith, they say thy pleasure lies in thy tongue; and therefore, though I do not give thee leave to lie with me, yet I will give thee as good a thing that will please thee as well.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Some roguery I expected.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: No faith, I am serious; and because I will please you both, master wild shall lie here, and you shall have leave to say you do, which will please you as well.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Faith, and my part is some pleasure, else, I have loved, enjoyed, and told, is mistook.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p:
Ay, but never to love, seldom enjoy, and always tell? Faugh, it stinks, and stains worse than Shoreditch dirt, and women hate and dread men for't; why, I that am a whore professed cannot see you, he digest it, though it be my profit and interest. For
to be a private whore in this town starves in the nest like young birds when the old one's killed.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Excellent girl, 'tis too true jolly; your tongue has kept, many a woman honest.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Faith, 'tis a truth, this I shall say, you may all better your pleasures by, if you will observe it; I dare say, the fear of telling keeps more women honest than Bridewell hemp; and were you wise men, and true lovers of liberty, now were the time to bring wenching to that perfection no age could ever have hoped; now you may sow such seed of pleasure, you may be prayed for hereafter; now, in this age of zeal and ignorance, would I have you four, in old clothes, and demure looks, present a petition to both houses, and say, you are men touched in conscience for your share in that wickendess which is known to their worships by the pleasure of adultery, and desire it may be death, and that a law may be passed to that purpose; how the women will pray for you, and at their own charges rear statues in memory of their benefactors; the young and kind would then haunt your chambers, pray, and present you, and court the sanguine youth, for the sweet sin secured by such a law; none would lose an occasion, nor churlishly oppose kind nature, nor refuse to listen to her summons, when youth and passion calls for those forbidden sweets; when such security as your lives are at stake, who would fear to trust; with this law all oaths and protestations are cancelled; letters and bawds would grow useless too; by instinct the kind will find the kind; and having one nature become of one mind; now we lose an age, to observe and know a man's humour, ere we dare trust him; but get this law, then 'tis, like and enjoy; and whereas now, with expense of time and fortune, you may glean some one mistress amongst your neighbour's wives, you shall reap women whole armfulls as in the common field; there is one small town, wise only in this law; and I have heard them say, that know it well, there has been but one execution this hundred years; yet the same party searched seven years, and could not find an honest woman in the town.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: An excellent plot, let us about it; ink and paper, dear wanton, we will draw the petition presently.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Will master jolly consent too? You must not then, as soon as a handsome woman is named, smile, and stroke your beard, tell him that is next you, you have lain with her; such a lie is as dangerous as a truth, and 'twere but justice to have thee hanged for a sin thou never committedst, for having defamed so many women.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: If all those liars were hanged, I believe the scale would weigh down the guilty.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: One rogue hanged, for example, would make a thousand kind girls: if it take it shall be called my law, wanton's law; then we may go in petticoats again, for women grew imperious and wore the breeches, only to fright the poor cuckolds, and make the fools digest their horns — are you all ready, shall I open the door?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll expect you at my house.

div.stage: [exit Wild one way, and the rest of the company another.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We'll come, we'll come.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: So, knock louder. They knock within, and the parson discovered in his bed and the bawd with him.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Who's there? what would you have?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Here's his majesty's watch, and master constable's worship must come in; we have a warrant from the lords to search for a delinquent.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: You come not here, I'll answer your warrant tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Break open the door.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I would you durst.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Lord! Dear what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Why, sweet, I'll warrant you, art thou not my wife, my rib, bone of my bone? I'll suffer any thing ere one hair of thee shall be touched.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Hark, they break open the door.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: They dare not; why dost thou tremble so? alas, sweet innocence, how it shakes?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Break open the door.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I'll complain to the Bishop of this insolence.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: They come, they come, lamb.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: No matter sweet; they dare not touch thee; what wouldHe delivers the warrant.you have Mr. Constable? you are very rude.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Read our warrant, and our business will excuse us? do you know any such person as you find there?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Yes, sir, but not by this name; such a woman is my wife, and no Lindabrides; we were married today, and I'll justify her my wife the next court day; you have your answer, and may be gone.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: We must take no notice of such excuses now; if she be your wife, make it appear in court, and she will be delivered unto you.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: If she be my wife sir? I have wedded her and bedded her, what other ceremonies would you have? Be not afraid, sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Sir, we can do no less than execute our warrant; we are but servants; and, master Constable, I charge you in the King's name to do your duty; behold the body of the delinquent.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p:
Touch her that dares; I'll put my dagger in him, fear
He takes his dagger ..
Here they strive to take her out.nothing, sweet heart; master Constable you'll repent this insolence offered to a man of my coat.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Help, my dearest, will you let me be haled thus?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Villains, what will you do? Murder, rape.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis likely; I look like a ravisher.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Hold him, and we'll do well enough with her.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What have we here, an old woman? As they go to pull her out of the bed, they discover the bawd. when they let him go he turn● to her, and holds her in his arms.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Let me go, slaves and murderers.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Let him go.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Do any of you know this woman? this is not she we looked for.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: No? Rascal, that mistake shall not excuse you.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: It is old goodman what d'ye call him? his wife.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hold the candle, and let's see her face.

div.stage: When they hold the candle, she lies in his bosom and his arms about her; she must be as nastily dressed as they can dress her; when he sees her he falls into a maze, and shoves her from him.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: What have were here, adultery? take them both, here will be new matter.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Master Constable, a little argument will persuade you to believe I am grossly abused; sure this does not look like a piece that a man would sin to enjoy, let that then move your pity, and care of my reputation; consider my calling, and do not bring me to a public shame for what you're sure I am not guilty of, but by plot of some villains.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Dear, will you disclaim me now?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: O, impudence!

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Master Constable, do your duty; take them both away, as you will answer it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Give him his cassock, to cover him. They put on his cassock and her coat, and lead them away.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Why gentlemen, whither will you carry me?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: To the next justice, I think it is master wild, he is newly come from travel, it will be a good way, neighbours, to express our respects to him.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: No faith, gentlemen, e'en go the next way to Tyburn, and dispatch the business without ceremony, for you'll utterly disgrace me; this is that damned captain; my wife is abroad too, I fear she is of the plot.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Come, away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Whither will they lead us, dear?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: O, o, impudence! Gentlemen, do not lead us together I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come, come, lead them together, no ceremonies; your faults are both alike.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. ii.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: You had best brag now, and use me like my lady whatest ye call; but if you do I care not.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, you're a fool, I'll be a faithful friend, and make good conditions for thee before thy husband be quit.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: You must do it now or never.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Hark, hark, I hear them — what's the news? Wild sits down with wanton in his lap.

div.stage: Enter captain, jolly, watch, bawd and parson.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: We have brought a couple of delinquents before your worship, they have committed a very foul fault.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: And we have brought the fault along too, that your worship may see it, you will be the better able to judge of the offenders.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Ha! what do I see? my wife in master justice's lap?

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: What has the poor fellow done?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why madam, he has been taken a-bed with this woman, another's man's wife.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: In bed with her? and do you raise him to punish him? Master Constable, if you would afflict him, command them to lie together again; is not the man mad?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: This is fine roguery, I find who rules the roast.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, to the business; you say, he was taken in bed with another man's wife.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Make his mittimus to the hole at Newgate.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: Sure I have seen this fellows face. — friend, have I never seen your face before?

sp.speaker: Parson
