sp.p: If I mistake not, I have seen one very like your ladyships too, she was a captain's cast-whore in the town. I shall have a time to be revenged.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How now, sirrah? are you threatening? away with him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll fetch a stronger watch, sir, and return presently.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Do, master Constable, and give the poor woman something, and set her free; for I dare say 'twas his wickedness, she looks like one that never thought on such a thing.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: God bless your worship, I am innocent; he never left making love till I consented.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: O miserable! miserable!

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How now, what's the news here? my honoured friend, and master parson, what makes you here at this time of night? Why I should have thought this a time to have envied you for your fair bride's embraces, do you give these favours? are these your bride-laces? It's a new way. Plays with the cord that binds his arms.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Is it new to you?

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: How now captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Wanton, is this your plot to endear your husband to you?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: No, 'tis thy plot, poor beaten captain, but I shall be revenged.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, faith, it was my plot, and I glory in't, to undermine my Machiavell, which so greedily swallowed that sweet bait that had this hook.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But my anger ends not here. Remember the base language you gave me, son of a thousand fathers, captain of a tame band, and one that got my living by the long staff-speeches; for which, and thy former treacheries, I'll ruin thee, slave; I'll have no more mercy on thee, then old women on blind puppies; I'll bring you to your commendations in Latin epistles again, nor leave thee any thing to live on, no, not bread, but what thou earn'st by raking gentlewomen's names in anagrams; and master justice, if ever you'll oblige me, stand to me now, that I may procure the whipping of him from the reverend bench.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I can do nothing but justice, you must excuse me; I shall only make it appear how fit it is to punish this kind of sin in that coat in time, and to crush such serpents in the shells.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Mercy, o mercy! They pull him away.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Officers, away with him.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: No mercy?

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Yes, upon conditions there may be some mercy. The parson looks very dejected.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And these they are — let the watch stay in the tother room. — first, your wife shall have her liberty, and you yours, as she reports of you; and when you bring her with you, you shall be welcome; than you shall not be jealous, that's another point.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That he shall have a cure for —

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Yes, yes, I'll apply something to his eyes shall cure him of his doubt.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Then you shall ask the captain pardon and your wife; to him you shall allow half your parsonage to maintain her; the deeds are ready within; if you'll sign them, and deliver your wife to our use, she shall discharge you.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I submit, sir, but I hope your worship will desire no witness to the use of my wife; the sumner and the watch too; I hope your worship will enjoin them silence.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: You shall not need to fear, I'll have a care of your credit;She discovers them.call in the watch; do you know these faces?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Ha! abused?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Nay, no flinching, if you do, I betake me to master Sumner again.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And I become severe master Constable in a trice.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: No, no, I submit, and I hope we are all friends; I'm sure I have the hardest part, to forgive.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: And I, before all this company, promise to forget and forgive thee, and am content to take thee again for my dear and mortal husband, now you are tame; but you must see you do so no more, and give yourself to be blind; when it is not fit for you to see; and practise to be deaf; and learn to sleep in time, and find business to call you away when gentlemen come that would be private.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why so, now things are as they should be; and when you will obey, you shall command: but when you would be imperious, than I betake me to my constable's staff till you subscribe. Cedunt armis togae; and if it be false Latin, parson, you must pardon that too.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: By this hand, I must have my tithe-night with thee; thou art such a wag; say, when? when wilt thou give me leave? ha!

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Never?

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: No, never.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Do ye hear, I am none of them that work for charity; either resolve to pay, or I kick down all my milk again.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Give me leave to lie with you.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: No; but rather than quarrel, as I said before, I will give you leave to say you have lain with me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am of opinion she owes you nothing now, so mistress wanton, take your husband; and to remove all doubts, this night I'll be at the charge of a wedding supper.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: This is better than Newgate hole yet, Bridewell hemp, brown bread and whipcord.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. iii.
div.stage: Enter the widow and mistress pleasant, master sad, and master Constant.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: By my troth, is was a good play.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And I am glad I am come home, for I am e'en as weary with this walking; for god's sake whereabouts does the pleasure of walking lie? I swear, I have often sought it till I was weary, and yet I could never find it. A watch at the widow's door.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: What do these halberds at your door?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Halberds, where?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: There, at your lodging.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Friend, what would those watchmen have?

sp.speaker: Vvatchm.
sp.p: The house is shut up for the sickness this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: The sickness?

sp.speaker: Vvatchm.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, there's a coachman dead full of the tokens.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Where is the officer?

sp.speaker: Vvatchm.
sp.p: He is gone to seek the lady of the house, and some other company that dined here yesterday, to bring her in, or carry her to the pest-house.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Ha! what shall we do, niece?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: If you please to command our lodging.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: It will be too much trouble.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Let's go to Loveall's.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Not I, by my faith; it is scarce for our credits to let her come to us.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Why? is she naught?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Faith, madam, her reputation is not good.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: But what shall we do then?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Dare you adventure to oblige us?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Thank you sir, we'll go to my nephews at Covent-garden; he may shift among his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: It was well thought on, the piazza is hard by too.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: We'll borrow your coach thither, and we'll send it you back again straight.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: We'll wait upon you, madam.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: This accident troubles me; I am heartily sorry for the poor fellow.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I am sorry too; but pray, aunt, let us not forget ourselves in our grief; I am not ambitious of a red-cross upon the door.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Mistress pleasant is in the right; for if you stay the officers will put you in.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: We shall trouble you, sir, for your coach.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. iv.
div.stage: Enter parson, captain, Wild, wanton, careless and jolly.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I am reconciled; and will no longer be an uncharitable churchman; I think this sack is a cooler.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What? does it make you to see your error?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Yes, and consider my man of war; nor will I again dispute his letters of mart, nor call them passes for pirates; I am free.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And welcome, any thing but anger is sufferable, and all is jest when you laugh; and I will hug thee for abusing me with thy eyes in their scabbards; but when you rail with drawn eyes, red and naked, threatening a Levites second revenge to all that touches your concubine, than I betake me to a darklanthorn, and a constables-staff, and by help of these fathers whom I cite I prove my text, women that are kind ought to be free.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: But captain, is it not lawful for us shepherds to reclaim them?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A mere mistake; for sin like the sea may be turned out, but will never grow less; and though you should drain this mistress doll, yet the whore will find a place, and perhaps overflow some maid, till then honest; and so you prove the author of a new sin, and the defiler of a pure temple; therefore I say, while you live, let the whore alone till she wears out; nor is it safe to vamp them, as you shall find, read ball the first and the second.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No more discourse. Strike up fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: See, who's that knocks?

div.stage: A country-dance. When they are merry, singing catches and drinking healths, the Wid. Mrs. Pleas. and the two lovers knock at the door.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis mistress pleasant, and the two gentlemen that dined there today.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: My aunt, and mistress pleasant.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: What a pox makes them abroad at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: It may be, they have been a wenching.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, they were upon alighting out of the coach when I came up.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Quickly, Mrs. wanton, you and your husband to bed, there's the key; Mr. parson, you know the way to the old chamber, and to it quickly, all is friends now.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Sweet heart, we'll steal away.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: The devil on them, they have spoilt our mirth.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Jack, get you and your company down the backway into the kitchen, and stay there till we see what this visit means.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Means! What should it mean? it is nothing but the mischievous nature all honest women are endued with, and naturally given to spoil sport: I wonder what fart blew them hither tonight .

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, have a little patience, captain; you and Mr. jolly must sit quietly a while within, till we know the cause.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: It is but deferring our mirth for an hour, or so. Servant. Sir, here's my lady.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Quickly remove those things there: captain, step in there. —

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Nephew, do you not wonder to see me here, at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I know it is not ordinary, therefore I believe 'tis some design: what is it, Mrs. pleasant? Shall I make one?

sp.speaker: Pleasant.
sp.p: As I live, sir, pure necessity; neither mirth nor kindness hath begotten this visit.

sp.speaker: Careless.
sp.p: What, is your coach broke?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Faith, nephew, the truth is, the sickness is in my house, and my coachman died since dinner.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The sickness?

sp.speaker: Pleasant.
sp.p: Ay, as I live, we have been walking since the play; and when we came home we found the watch at the door, and the house shut up.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: And a constable gone in search of all those that dined there today, with order to furnish us lodgings in the pest-house.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Are you not afraid to receive us?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: As I live, the accident troubles me; and I am sorry such a misfortune should beget me this favour; and I could wish myself free from the honour, if the cause were removed too.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: As I live, Mr. wild, I must have been forced to have lain with my servant tonight , if you had not received me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If I thought so, I would carry you out in my arms, I am so much Mr. Constant's friend.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: But are you more his friend than mine, Mr. wild?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, but I presume by this he has gained so much interest as he would not be very displeasing to you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh! your humble servant, sir.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: If I had had a mind to that lodging, I had never come hither; for when I have a mind to it, I'll marry without dispute; for I fear nobody so much as a husband; and when I can conquer that doubt, I'll marry at a minute's warning.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: No dispute now, can you furnish us with a couple of beds?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And have you ere a woman in the house?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: My sister's maid is here.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Madam, if you resolve to do us this honour, you shall find clean linen, and your beds quickly ready.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: But where will my nephew and you, sir, lie tonight ?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: O, madam, we have acquaintance enough in the town.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Well, sir, we'll accept this courtesy; and when you come into Suffolk you shall command my house.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Prithee call Bess, and bid her bring sheets to make the bed; I'll go and fetch in a pallet, 'tis as good a bed as the other, and if you will stay the removing, we'll set up a bedstead.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: No, a pallet, pray; but what shall we do for night clothes, aunt?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why, what are those you bought my sisters?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Is not that linen gone yet?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No faith, madam, his man forgotten it, till the carriers were gone last week.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Will that serve?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Yes, yes, pray do us the favour to let us have it, 'tis but washing of't again.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, if it will serve, discourse no more; I'll fetch the bundle; and prithee fetch the combs and looking glasses I bought the other day; for other necessaries that want a name the wench shall furnish you with.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Nay, but where is she, nephew?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll call her, if she be not gone to bed; it is an ignorant young thing, I am to send her to my sisters in the country; I have had such ado to put her in the fashion.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: What country is she? Prithee, Mr. wild, let's see her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll call her down.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Madam, now we see you're safe we'll kiss your hands, and wait upon you tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: It must be early then, sir; for I shall borrow my nephew's coach, and be gone betimes into the country to take a little fresh air, and prevent the search.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Pray, madam, be pleased to command ours.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: No, sir, I humbly thank you; my nephew's will hold our company.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Your humble servant, mistress pleasant.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Your servant, madam.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Good night, Mr. constant.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Sir, you'll excuse us, we have nobody here to light you down.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Madam, I am here your servant as much as those that wear your livery; and this house holds no other; we can be civil, madam, as well as extravagant.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Your humble servant, Mr. careless.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Gentlemen, if you'll wait on my lady to her chamber, then I'll wait upon you down.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: You oblige us, sir.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. v.
div.stage: Enter Wild, captain, wanton, parson and jolly.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The plague?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The plague; as I live, and all my relation is truth, every syllable; but, Mrs. wanton, now must you play your masterpiece; be sure to blush, and appear but simple enough, and all is well; thou wilt pass for as arrant a chambermaid as any is in the parish.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Hum! new plots?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Let me put on a petticoat and a muffler, and I'll so chambermaid it, and be so diligent with the clean smock and the chamber-pot: now would I give all the shoes in my shop to lie with 'em both.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Let me alone to fit them, I can make a scurvy curtsy naturally; remember, I am an Essex woman, if they ask.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, come quickly, take those sweetmeats; bring the great cake and knife, and napkins, for they have not supped; and captain, make some lemonade, and send it by the boy to my chamber; and do you hear, jolly, you must stay till we come, for we must lie with you tonight .

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: We'll stay, but make haste then.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And bring our cloaks and swords out with you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I will, I will; but be quiet all.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Mr. wild, I hope there is no plot in this.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: There's no jealousy, Mr. parson; 'tis all serious upon my life.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. vi.
div.stage: The tyring-room, curtains drawn, and they discourse, his chamber, two beds, two tables, looking-glasses, night-clothes, waste-coats, sweet-bags, sweetmeats and wine, wanton dressed like a chambermaid; all above if the scene can be so ordered.
Enter widow and Mrs. pleasant, Wild and careless; the widow and Mrs. pleasant salute wanton.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith, aunt, 'tis the first time I have had the honour to see you in my house; and as a stranger I must salute you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: As I live, nephew, I'm ashamed to put you to this trouble.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It is an obligation. — Mrs. pleasant, I know you have not supped; I pray you be pleased to taste these sweetmeats, they are of Sall's doing; but I understand not sweetmeats, the wine I'll answer for; and, in a word, you are welcome: you are patrona, and we your slaves.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Good rest, and a pleasing dream, your humble servant wishes you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Good night, nephew; good night, Mr. careless.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Good night, Mr. careless; your humble servant, Mr. wild.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why I, here are men have some wit; by this good night, had we lain at my servants, we should have found the laced cap and slippers that have been entailed upon the family these five descents, advanced upon the cup-boards-head instead of plate. They sit down to undress them.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: They are a couple of the readiest youths too; how they run and do all things with a thought! I love him for sending his sister, a pretty wench.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Pray, let's go to bed; I am weary.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: You will not go to bed with all those windows open; sweet heart, prithee shut them, and bring me hither; — dost understand me? As I live, 'tis a great while since I went to the play.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: It has been one of the longest days; a year of them would be an age.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: O, do you grow weary; you'll break your covenant ere the year go out.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Prithee, shut the windows, and come pin up my hair. The curtains are closed.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. vii.
div.stage: Enter Wild, jolly, careless, captain and parson, and fiddlers, and one with a torch, with their cloaks and their swords, putting them on. Enter Wild's man.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: See you wait diligently, and let them want nothing they call for; come shall we go? 'tis very late.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But how does wanton carry it?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: They saluted her; and Mrs. pleasant swore you might see the country-simplicity in her face.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: A pox upon her, crafty Gipsy.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, art not thou glad to see she can be honest when she will?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I'll show you all a trick, for her, within these few days, or I'll miss my aim.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Come, let's go. They all offer to go.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I have a mind to stay till wanton comes.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Stay a little then, for 'twill not be long ere they be a-bed .

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I hear wanton's voice.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Are they a-bed ?

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: Yes, and have so admired you, and Mr. careless, and abused the lovers; well, gentlemen, you are the wits of the time; but if I might counsel, well they might lie alone this night; but it should go hard if I lay not with one of them within a month.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Were they so taken with their lodging?

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p:
All that can be said they said, you are the friendliest men, the readiest men, the handsom'st men that had wit; and could tell when to be civil, and when to be wild; and Mrs. (What's her
name) the younger, asked why Mr. wild did not go a-wooing to some rich heir; upon her conscience, she said, you would speed.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well, well, there's a time for all things; come let's go.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Take a light. — good night, wanton. They offer to depart.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: D'ye hear, d'ye hear; let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What's the business? They all come back again.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I cannot get hence this night: but your good angels hang at my heels; and if I can prevail, you shall stay.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What to do? why I'll be hanged if all this company do not guess.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Prithee, what should we stay for?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: For the widow, and her niece; are they worth the watching for a night?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Then take my counsel, and let me give it out you're married, you have new clothes come home this morning, and there's that you spoke of I'll fetch from the tailors, and here's a parson shall rather give them his living, then stay for a licence; the fiddlers too are ready to salute 'em.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But if they refuse?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Which, upon my conscience, they will.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: As you hope, else you are laughed at for missing the widow: Ned, follow my counsel, appear at her chamber window in thy shirt, and salute all that passes by; let me alone to give it out, and invite company and provide dinner; then when the business is known, and I have presented all your friends at court with ribbons, she must consent, or her honour is lost, if you have but the grace to swear it, and keep your own counsel.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By this hand, he has reason; and I'll undertake the widow.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It will incense them, and precipitate the business which is in a fair way now; and if they have wit, they must hate us for such a treachery.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: If they have wit they will love you; beside, if it come to that, we two will swear we saw you married, and the parson shall be sworn he did it: — priest, will you not swear?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Yes, any thing; what is't, captain?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If this jest could do it, yet 'tis base to gain a wife so poorly; she came hither too for sanctuary; it would be an uncivil and an unhospitable thing, and look as if I had not merit enough to get a wife without stealing her from herself; then, 'tis in mine own house.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The better; nay, now I think on't, why came she hither? how do you know the plague is there? all was well at dinner; I'll be hanged if it be not a plot; the lovers too whom you abused at dinner, are joined with them; a trick, a mere trick of wit to abuse us; and tomorrow when the birds are flown, they'll laugh at you, and say, two country ladies put themselves naked into the hands of three travelled city-wits, and they durst not lay hold on them.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A pox upon these niceties.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: If they have not some design upon you hang me, why did they talk so freely before me else?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let's but try, we are not now to begin to make the world talk; nor is it a new thing to them to hear we are mad fellows.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: If you get them, are they worth having?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Having? yes.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: If you miss them the jest is good; prithee, Ned, let me prevail, 'tis but a mad trick.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If we would, how shall we get into the chamber?

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Let me alone for that; I'll put on my country simplicity, and carry in a chamber pot; then under pretence of bolting the back door I'll open it, and yet I grudge them the sport so honestly; for you wenchers make the best husbands; after you are once married, one never see's you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I warrant thee wench.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: No faith, I have observed it, they are still the dotingest husbands, and then retreat and become justices of the peace, and none so violent upon the bench, as they, against us poor sinners; yet I'll do it, for upon my conscience the young gentlewoman will fall upon her back, and thank me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Away, go then, and leave your fooling, and in the morning, Ned, get in, and plead naked with your hands in the bed.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: And if they cry, put your lips in their mouths, and stop them.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why look you, you have the authority of the church too.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, I am now resolved; go you about your part, and make the report strong.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And d'ye here? be sure you set the cook at work, that if we miss we may have a good dinner, and good wine, to drink down our grief.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Miss? I warrant thee thrive.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay, if I knock not down the widow, geld me, and come out tomorrow complete uncle, and salute the company, with, you are welcome gentlemen, and good morrow nephew Ned.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Uncle Tom, good morrow, uncle Tom.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: All's done, the door is open, and they're as still as children's thoughts; 'tis time you made you ready, which is, to put off your breeches, for 'tis almost day; and take my council, be sure to offer force enough, the less reason will serve; especially you, master wild, do not put a maid to the pain of saying, I.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I warrant thee, wench; let me alone.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: We'll in, and undress us, and come again; for we must go in at the back door.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll meet you, is the captain gone?

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he's gone.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p:
Come master parson, let us see the cook in readiness, where are the fiddlers? what will become of our plot? for the
coachman; master sad and his friend will stink of their jest if this thrive.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: They have slept all night, on purpose, to play all day.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: When the ribbons and points come from the exchange, pray see the fiddlers have some, the rogues will play so out of tune all day else, they will spoil the dancing if the plot do take.

div.stage: Enter Wild, and careless, in their shirts, with drawers under; night-gowns on, and in slippers.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Let's see them in the chamber first, and then I shall go with some heart about the business; so, so, creep close and quietly; you know the way, the widow lies in the high bed, and the pallet is next the door.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
Must we creep?
They kneel at the door to go in.
She shakes her coats over 'em.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Yes, yes, down upon your knees, always, till you get a woman, and then stand up for the cause; stay let me shake my smock over you for luck's sake.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Why so, I warrant you thrive.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: A pox take you, I'll pare your nails when I get you from this place once.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Sweet heart, sweet heart, off with your shoe.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart, there's an old shoe after you; would I gave all in my shop the rest were furnished with wives too.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Parson, the sun is rising, go send in the fiddlers, and set the cook on work, let him chap soundly.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I have a tithe big at home, I'll e'en sacrifice it to the wedding.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: They will find them in good posture, they may take privy marks if they please; for they said it was so hot they could endure no clothes, and my simplicity was so diligent to lay them naked, and with such 'Twists and turns fastened them to the feet, I'll answer for't, they find not the way into them in an hour.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Why then they may pull up their smocks, and hide their faces?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Master jolly, there was one without would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Who was it?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: It is the lady that talks so well.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: They say indeed she has an excellent tongue, I would she had changed it for a face; 'tis she that has been handsome.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Who? not the poetess we met at master Sadd's?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Yes, the same.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Sure she's mad.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Prithee tell her I am gone to bed.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I have done as well sir; I told her mistress wanton was here, at which discreetly, being touched with the guilt of her face, she threw out a curse or two and retreated.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Who is this you speak of, I will know who 'tis.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Why 'tis she that married the Genoese merchant; they cozened one another.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Who? Pegg Driver, bugle eyes?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: The same, the same.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Why she is ugly now?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Yes, but I have known her, by this hand, as fine a wench as ever sinned in town or suburbs; when I knew her first, she was the original of all the wainscot chambermaids, with brooms, and barefoot madams, you see sold at Temple-bar, and the exchange.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Ah! thou'rt a devil; how couldst thou find in thy heart to abuse her so? Thou lovest antiquities too; the very memory that she had been handsome should have pleaded something.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Was handsome signifies nothing to me.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: But she's a wit, and a wench of an excellent discourse.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: And as good company as any's i'th town.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Company? for whom? Leather-ears, his majesty of Newgate watch? There her story will do well, while they louse themselves.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Well, you are curious now, but the time was, when you have skipped for a kiss.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Prithee, parson, no more of wit, and was handsome, butHe kisses wanton.let us keep to this text — and with joy think upon thy little wanton here, that's kind, soft, sweet and sound; these are epithets for a mistress; nor is there any elegancy in a woman like it; give me such a naked scence, to study night and day; I care not for her tongue, so her face be good; a whore dressed in verse, and set speeches, tempts me no more to that sweet sin, than the statute of whipping can keep me from it; this thing we talked on, which retains nothing but the name of what she was, is not only poetical in her discourse, but her tears and her love, her health, nay her pleasure, were all fictions, and had scarce any live-flesh about her till I administered.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Indeed 'tis time she sat out, and gave others leave to play; for a dramatic whore is an unseemly sight; besides it makes the sin malicious, which is but venial else.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Sure, he'll make a case of conscience on't; you should do well (Sweet heart) to recommend her case to your brothers that attend the committee of affection, that they may order her to be sound and young again, for the good of the commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: O, are you ready? are you ready?

sp.speaker: Fiddlers.
sp.p: Yes, an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: And did you bid the cook chop lustily, and make a noise?

sp.speaker: Fiddlers.
sp.p: Yes, sir, he's at it.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: I hear the captain.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Have you brought clothes and ribbons?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, yes, all is ready; did you hear them squeak yet?

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: No, by this light; I think, 'tis an appointment, and we have been all abused.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Give the fiddlers their ribbons, and carry the rest in; mistress wanton, you must play my lady's woman today, and mince it to all that come, and hold up your head finely when they kiss you, and take heed of swearing when you are angry, and pledging whole cups when they drink to you.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: I'll warrant you, for my part.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Go get you in then, and let your husband dip the rosemary.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Is all ready?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: All, all, some of the company are below already, I have so blown it about, one porter is gone to the exchange, to invite master Wild's merchant to his wedding, and, by the way to bid two or three fruiterers to send in fruit for such a wedding, another in my lady's name to sall's, for sweet meats; I swore at Bradborn in his shop myself, that I wondered he would disappoint master wild for his points, and having so long warning; he protested 'twas not his fault, but they were ready, and he would send John with them presently; one of the watermen is gone to the melon garden, the other to cooks at the bear, for some bottles of his best wine, and thence to Gracious-street, to the poulterers, and all with directions to send in provisions for master Wild's wedding; and who should I meet at door, but apricock Tom, and Mary, waiting to speak with her young master; they came to beg that they might serve the feast; I promised them they should, if they would cry it up and down the town, to bring company; for master wild was resolved to keep open house.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Why then here will be witnesses enough.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But who should I meet at the corner of the piazza, but Joseph tailor; he tells me, there's a new play at the friars today, and I have bespoke a box for master wild and his bride.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: And did not he wonder to hear he was married?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes; but I told him, 'twas a match his aunt made for him, when he was abroad.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: And I have spread it sufficiently at court, by sending to borrow plate for such a wedding.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: There's half a dozen coach fulls of company lighted; they call for the bride-laces and points.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Let the fiddlers play then, and bid God give them joy, by the name of my lady careless and mistress wild.

sp.speaker: Fiddler
sp.p: Where shall we play, sir?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Come with us, we'll show you the window.

div.head: Act. v. scen. ii.
div.stage: The fiddlers play in the tyring room, and the stage curtains are drawn, and discover a chamber, as it was, with two beds and the ladies asleep in them; master Wild being at mistress pleasant's bedside, and master careless at the widow's; the music awakes the widow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Niece, niece, niece pleasant.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Ha! I hear you, I hear you, what would you have? She opens the curtain and calls her, she is under a canopy.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Do you not hear the fiddlers?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but you have waked me from the finest dream.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: A dream, what was't? some knavery.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, I know not, but 'twas merry, e'en as pleasing as some sins; well, I'll lie no more in a man's bed, for fear I lose more than I get.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Hark, that's a new tune.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Yes, and they play it well; this is your jaunty nephew; I would he had less of the father in him, I'd venture to dream out my dream with him; in my conscience he's worth a dozen of my dull servant, that's such a troublesome visitant, without any kind of conveniency.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Ay, ay, so are all of that kind; give me your subject lover; those you call servants are but troubles, I confess.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: What is the difference, pray, betwixt a subject, and a servant lover?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why, one I have absolute power over, the other's at large; your servant lovers are those take mistresses upon trial, scarce give them a quarter's warning before they are gone.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, what do your subject lovers do? I am so sleepy.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Do? All things for nothing; than they are the diligentest and the humblest things a woman can employ; nay, I ha' seen of them tame, and run loose about a house; I had one once, by this light, he would fetch and carry, go back, seek out, he would do any thing; I think some falconer bred him.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: By my troth, I am of your mind.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: He would come over, for all my friends; but it was the doggedest thing to my enemies, he would sit upon's tail before them, and frown, like John a napes when the Pope is named; he heard me once praise my little spaniel bitch Smut for waiting, and hang me if I stirred for seven years after, but I found him lying at my door.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And what became of him?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Faith, when I married he forsook me; I was advised since, that if I would ha' spit in's mouth sometimes he would have stayed.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p:
That was cheap, but 'tis no certain way; for 'tis a general opinion, that marriage is one of the certainest cures for love that one can apply to a man that is sick of the sighings; yet if you were to live about this town still, such a fool would do you a
world of service; I'm sure secret will miss him, and would always take such a care of her has saved her a hundred walks for hoods and masques.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Yes, and I was certain of the earliest fruits and flowers that the spring afforded.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: By my troth, 'twas foolishly done to part with him; a few crumbs of your affection would have satisfied him, poor thing.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Thou art in the right; in this town there's no living without 'em; they do more service in a house for nothing, than a pair of those, what-d'ye-call'ems' , those he waiting-women, beasts, that custom impose upon ladies.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Is there none of them to be had now, think you? I'd feign get a tame one, to carry down into the country.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Faith, I know but one breed of them about the town that's right, and that's at the court; the lady that has them brings 'em all up by hand; she breeds some of them from very puppies; there's another wit too in the town that has of them; but hers will not do so many tricks; good sullen diligent waiters those are which she breeds, but not half so serviceable.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: How does she do it? is there not a trick in't?

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Only patience, but she has a heavy hand with 'em (They say) at first, and many of them miscarry; she governs them with signs, and by the eye, as bank's breeds his horse; there are some too that arrive at writing, and those are the right breed, for they commonly betake themselves to poetry; and if you could light on one of them, 'twere worth your money; for 'tis but using of him ill, and praising his verses sometimes, and you are sure of him for ever.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: But do they never grow surly, aunt?

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Not, if you keep them from raw flesh, for they are a kind of lion-lovers; and if they once taste the sweet of it, they'll turn to their kind.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Lord, aunt, there will be no going without one this summer into the country; pray let's inquire for one; either a he one to entertain us, or a she one to tell us the story of her love; 'tis excellent to bedward, and makes one as drowsy as prayers.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Faith, niece, this parliament has so destroyed 'em, and the Platonic humour, that 'tis uncertain whether we shall get one or no; your leading members in the lower house have so cowed the ladies, that they have no leisure to breed any of late; their whole endeavours are spent now in feasting, and winning close committee-men, a rugged kind of sullen fellows, with implacable stomachs and hard hearts, that make the gay things court and observe them, as much as the foolish lovers use to do; yet I think I know one she-lover, but she is smitten in years o'th wrong side of forty; I am certain she is poor too; and in this lean age for courtiers, she perhaps would be glad to run this summer in our park ▪

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Dear aunt, let us have her; has she been famous? has she good tales, think you, of knights? such as have been false or true to love, no matter which.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: She cannot want cause to curse the sex; handsome, witty, well born, and poor in court, cannot want the experience how false young men can be; her beauty has had the highest fame; and those eyes that weep now unpitied have had their envy, and a dazling power.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And that tongue, I warrant you, which now grows hoarse with flattering the great law-breakers, once gave law to princes; was it not so aunt? Lord, shall I die without begetting one story?

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Penthesilea, nor all the cloven knights the poets treat of, clad in mightiest petticoats, did her excel for gallant deeds; and, with her honour, still preserved her freedom; my brother loved her; and I have heard him swear, Minerva might have owned her language; an eye like Pallas, Juno's wrists, a Venus for shape, and a mind chaste as Diana, but not so rough; never uncivilly cruel, nor faulty kind to any; no vanity, that sees more than lovers pay, nor blind to a gallant passion; her maxim was, he that could love, and tell her so handsomely, was better company, but not a better lover than a silent man; thus, all passions found her civility, and she a value from all her lovers. But alas, niece, this was (Which is a sad word) was handsome, and was beloved, are abhorred sounds in women's ears. The fiddlers play again.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Hark, the fiddlers are merry still; will not secret have the wit to find us this morning, think you?

sp.speaker: Fiddlers.
sp.p: God give you joy, master careless; God give your ladyship joy, my lady wild.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: What did the fellow say? God give me joy?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: As I live, I think so.

sp.speaker: Fiddlers.
sp.p: God give you joy, mistress pleasant wild.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: This is my nephew, I smell him in this knavery.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why did they give me joy by the name of mistress wild? I shall pay dear for a night's lodging if that be so, especially lyingAll the company confused without, and bid God give them joy.alone; by this light, there is some knavery afoot.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Rise, rise, for shame, the year's afore you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, Ned wild, why Tom, will you not rise and let's in? what, is it not enough to steal your wedding over night, but lock yourselves up in the morning too? All your friends stay for points here, and kisses from the brides.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A little patience, you'll give us leave to dress us? The women squeeke when they speak.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why, what's o'clock , captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: It's late.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Faith, so it was before we slept.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why, nephew, what means this rudeness? As I live, I'll fall out with you. This is no jest.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, as I live, aunt. We are in earnest; but my part lies here, and there's a gentleman will do his best to satisfy you;They catch the women in their arms.and sweet mistress pleasant, I know you have so much wit as to perceive this business cannot be remedied by denials; here we are, as you see, naked, and thus have saluted hundreds at the window that passed by, and gave us joy this morning.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Joy, of what? what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Madam, this is visible, and you may coy it, and refuse to call me husband; but I am resolved to call you wise, and suchCareless kisses the widow.proofs I'll bring as shall not be denied.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Promise yourself that; see whether your fine wits can make it good; you will not be uncivil?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Not a hair but what you give, and that was in the contract before we undertook it; for any man may force a woman's body, but we have laid we will force your mind.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But that needs not, for we know by your discourse last night and this morning, we are men you have no aversion to; and I believe, if we had taken time and wooed hard, this would have come a course; but we had rather win you by wit, because you defied us.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, if it succeed.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And, for my part, but for the jest of winning you, and this way, not ten jointures should have made me marry?

sp.speaker: Vvid,
sp.p: This is a new way of wooing.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Tis so, madam; but we have not laid our plot so weakly (Though it were sudden) to leave it in anybody's power but our own to hinder it.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: We are secure enough, if we can be true to ourselves.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yet we submit in the midst of our strength, and beg you will not wilfully spoil a good jest by refusing us. By this hand, we are both sound, and we'll be strangely honest, and never in ill humours, but live as merry as the maids, and divide the year between the town and the country; what say you, is't a match? Your bed is big enough for two, and my meat will not cost you much; I'll promise nothing but one heart, one purse betwixt us, and a whole dozen of boys, is't a bargain?

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Not, if I can hinder it, as I live.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith, mistress pleasant, he hath spoken nothing but reason, and I'll do my best to make it good; come faith, teach my aunt what to do, and let me strike the bargain upon your lips.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: No, sir, not to be half a Queen; if we should yield now your wit would domineer for ever; and still in all disputes (Though never so much reason on our side) this shall be urged as an argument of your master wit to confute us; I am of your aunt's mind, sir; and if I can hinder it, it shall be no match.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why then know, it is not in your powers to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why, we are not married yet.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: By this good light then I'll be dumb for ever hereafter, lest I light upon the words of marriage by chance.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: 'Tis hard, when our own acts cannot be in our own power, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The plot is only known to four, the minister and two that stood for fathers, and a simple country maid that waited upon you last night, which plays your chambermaid's part.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And what will all these do?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why, the two friends will swear, they gave you; the parson will swear, he married you; and the wench will swear, she put us to bed.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Have you men to swear we are married?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And a parson to swear he did it?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And a wench that will swear, she put us to bed?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Yes, by this good light, and witness of reputation.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Dare they or you look us in the face, and swear this?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes faith, and all but those four know no other but really it is so; and you may deny it, but I'll make Mr. Constable put you to bed, with this proof, at night.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Pray, let's see these witnesses.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Call in the four only.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Well, this shall be a warning to me; I say nothing, but if ever I lie from home again.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll lie with you.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: 'Tis well; I dare say, we are the first women (If this take) that ever were stolen against their wills.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll go call the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: I that have refused a fellow that loved me these seven years, and would have put off his hat, and thanked me to come to bed, to be beaten with watchmen's staves into another's; for by this good light, for ought that I perceive, there's no keeping these out at night.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And unless we consent to be their wives, today, m. justice will make us their whores at night: o, o, what would not I give to come off! not that I mislike them, but I hate they should get us thus.

div.stage: Enter Wild, jolly, captain, careless, parson, wanton, with rosemary in their hands, and points in their hats.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Follow. — will not you two swear we were married last night?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Captain. Yes, by this light, will we.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Will not you swear you married us?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Yea, verily.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And come hither, pretty one, will not you swear you left us all a-bed last night, and pleased?

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Yes forsooth; I'll swear any thing your worship shall appoint me.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: But, gentlemen, have you no shame, no conscience; will you swear false, for sport?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: By this light, I'll swear, if it be but to vex you: remember you refused me, [that is contrary to covenants though with my brace of lovers; what will they do with their coach-mansSpeaks these words, aside.plot? but 'tis no matter, I have my ends; and so they are cozened I care not who does it.]

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And, faith, madam, I have sworn many times false, to no purpose; and I should take it ill, if it were mine own case, to have a friend refuse me an oath upon such an occasion.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And are you all of one mind?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Verily we will all swear.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Will you verily? what shall we do, aunt? Pleas. laughs.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Do you laugh? By this light, I am heartily angry.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, as I live, let's marry them, aunt, and be revenged.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Marry, where's the parson?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Here, here, m. parson, come and do your office.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: That fellow? No, by my troth, let's be honestly joined, for lucks sake, we know not how soon we may part.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What shall she do for a parson? Captain, you must run and fetch one.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, yes; but methinks this might serve turn; by this hand, he's a marshal, and a case, by sire and dam; pray try him, by this light, he comes of the best preaching kind in Essex.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Not I, as I live, that were a blessing in the devil's name.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: A pox on your wedding; give me my wife and let me be gone.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nay, nay, no choler, parson; the ladies do not like the colour of your beard.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: No, no, fetch another, and let them escape with that trick, than they'll jeer your beards blue, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By this hand, he's in the right; either this parson, or take one another's words; to bed now, and marry when we rise.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: As I live, you come not here till you are married; I have been nobody's whore yet, and I will not begin with my husband.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Will you kiss upon the bargain, and promise before these witnesses not to spoil our jest, but rise and go to church.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And what will m. constant and m. Sad say?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, I'll run and invite them to the wedding; and you shall see them expire in their own garters.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: No, no, never fear't, their jest is only spoiled.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Their jest, what jest?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Faith, now you shall know it, and the whole plot: in the first place, your coachman is well, whose death, we, by the help of secret, contrived, thinking by that trick to prevent this danger, and carry you out of town.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But had they this plot?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Yes faith, and see how it thrives; they'll fret like carted bawds when they hear this news.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, aunt; would you have thought m. Sad a plotter? well, 'tis some comfort we have them to laugh at.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Nay faith, then, gentlemen, give us leave to rise, and I'll take my venture, if it be but for a revenge on them.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Gentlemen, bear witness.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come, come away, I'll get the points; I'm glad the coachman's well, the rogue had like to have spoilt our comedy.

div.head: Act. v. scen. iii.
div.stage: Enter the lady Loveall, master sadd, and constant, undressed and buttoning themselves as they go.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Married?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And to them?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ay, married, if you prevent it not; catched with a trick, an old stale trick; I have seen a ballad on't.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: We shall go near to prevent 'em. — boy, my sword.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Whither so fast?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: You guess.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: If you mean the wedding, you come too late.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why, are they married?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No, but lustily promised.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: We may come time enough to be revenged though. —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Upon whom? yourselves, for you are only guilty: who carried them thither last night? who laid the plot for the coachman?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Why, do they know it?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, you'll find the poet a rogue, 'tis he that has betrayed you; and if you'll take my counsel, be revenged upon him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, we were told he did not love us.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By my life, you wrong him; upon my knowledge the poet meant you should have them.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Why, who had the power to hinder then?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I know not where the fault lies directly; they say, the wits of the town would not consent to't, they claim a right in the ladies, as orphan-wits.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: The wits! hang 'em in their strong lines.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why I, such a clinch as that has undone you; and upon my knowledge 'twere enough to hinder your next match.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Why, what have they to do with us?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I know not what you have done to disoblige them; but they crossed it; there was amongst 'em too a pair of she-wits, something stricken in years; they grew in fury at the mention of it, and concluded you both with an authority out of a modern author; besides 'tis said, you run naturally into the sixpenny room and steal sayings, and a discourse more than your pennyworth of jests, every term; why, just now, you spit out one jest stolen from a poor play, that has but two more in five acts; what conscience is there in't, knowing how dear we pay poets for our plays?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Twas, madam, with the ill face, one of those whom you refused to salute the other day, at Chip's house; a cheesecake had saved all this.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why do you not make haste about your business, but lose time with this babbler?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Madam, will you give us leave to make use of your coach?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You may command it, sir; when you have done, send him to the exchange, where I'll dispatch a little business, and be with you immediately.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: So, this fire's kindled; put it out that can. What would not I give for a peeper's place at the meeting; I'll make haste, and it shall go hard but I'll bear my part of the mirth too.

div.head: Act. v. scen. iv.
div.stage: Enter widow, pleasant, careless, Wild, parson, jolly, wanton and secret: the fiddlers play as they come in.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Master jolly, I find I am naturally inclined to mirth this day, and methinks my corns ache more than my horns; and to a man that has read Seneca a cuckold ought to be no grief; especially in this parish where I see such droves of st. Luke's clothing; there's little secret too, th'allay of waiting-woman, makes me hope, she may prove metal of the parson's standard. Find a way to rid me of wanton, and I'll put in to be chaplain to this merry family; if I did not inveigle formal secret, you should hang me; I know the trick on't; 'tis but praying too, and preaching of the waiting-woman, then carefully seeing her cushion laid, with her book and leaf turned down, does it, with a few anagrams, acrostics, and her name in the register of my bible: these charm the soft-souled sinner; then sometimes to read a piece of my sermon, and tell her, a Saturday, where my text shall be, spells that work more than philtres.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: If you can be serious, we'll think of this at leisure. — see how they eye wanton.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What? consulting parson? let us be judges betwixt you; d'ye hear, Jack, if he offers ready money, I counsel, as a friend, take it; for, by this light, if you refuse it, your wife will not; d'ye see those gay petticoats?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Yes, if you mean my wife's.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You know they're his, and she only wears 'em for his pleasure; and 'tis dangerous to have a wife under another man's petticoats; what if you should find his breeches upon hers?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Are not you married too? take care that yours does not wear the breeches, another kind of danger, but as troublesome as that, or sore-eyes; and if she get but a trick of taking as readily as she's persuaded to give, you may find a horn at home; I have seen a cuckold of your complexion; if he had had as much hoof as horn, you might have hunted the beast by his slat.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p:
How fine she is! and, by this light, a handsome wench, Mr. jolly, I am easier persuaded to be reconciled to your fault, than any man's; I have seen, of this kind; her eyes have more arguments in 'em then a thousand of those that seduce the world; hang me if those quivers be not full of darts; I could kiss that mouth,
myself, is this she my aunt quarrelled with you for?

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: The same, selfsame. And by this hand, I was barbarous to her, for your aunt's sake; and had I not scaped that mischief of matrimony, by this light, I had had never seen her again; but I was resolved not to quit her, till I was sure of a wife, for fear of what has followed; had I been such an ass as to have left her upon the airy hopes of a widow's oaths; what a case had I been in now? You see, your aunt's provided of a man. Bless him, and send him patience, 'twould have been fine to have seen me walking, and sighing upon cold hunting, seeking my whore again, or forced to make use of some common mercenary thing that sells sin and diseases, crimes, penance and sad repentance together; here's consolation and satisfaction, in wanton, though a man lose his meal with the widow. And, faith, be free, how do you like my girl; rid thee of her; what does she want now, pray, but a jointure, to satisfy any honest man? speak your conscience; ladies don't you think a little repentance, hereafter, will serve, for all the small sins that good nature can act with such a sinner?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Pray, sir, remember she's my wife; and be so civil to us both, as to forget these things.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: For that, Jack, we'll understand hereafter, 'tis but a trick of youth, man, and her jest ill make us both merry, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Pray, sir, no more of your jests, nor your Jack; remember my coat and calling. This familiarity both with my wife and myself, is not decent; your clergy with Christen names are scarce held good Christians.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I wonder at nothing so much as m. Jollies mirth, today; where lies his part of the jest? cozened or refused by all, not a fish that stays in's net. Joll. bugs Wanton.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: No, what's this? show me a fairer in all your streams; nor is this my single joy, who am pleased to find you may be cozened; rejoice to see you may be brought to lie with a man for a jest; let me alone to fit you with a trick too.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Faith, it must be some new trick; for thou art so beaten at the old one, 'twill neither please thee nor her; besides, I mean to teach her that myself.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I shall never be perfectly quiet in my mind, till I see somebody as angry as myself; yet I have some consolation when I think on the wise plot that killed the coachman, how the plague, red-cross and halberd has cut their fingers that designed it, their anger will be perfect. Secret says they are coming, and that the lady Loveall has given 'em the alarm.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And see where the parties come, — storms and tempests in their minds, their looks are daggers.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Servant, what? you're melancholy and full of wonder; I see you have met the news.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Yes madam, we have heard a report that will concern both your judgement and your honour.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Alas, sir, we're innocent; 'tis mere predestination.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: All weddings, Mr. sad, you know go by chance, like hanging.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And, I thank my stars, I have scaped hanging; to ha' been his bride had been both.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: This is not like the promise you made us yesterday.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why truly, servant, I scarce know what I do yet; the fright of the plague had so possessed my mind with fear that I could think and dream of nothing, last night, but of a tall black man, that came and kissed me in my sleep, and slapped his whip in mine ears, 'twas a saucy ghost, (Not unlike my coachman that's dead) and accused you of having a hand in his murder, and vowed to haunt me till I was married, I told my niece the dream.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Nay, the ghost sighed, and accused secret and master sad; of making him away confess, faith, had you a hand in that bloody jest?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Fie, servant; could you be so cruel as to join with my woman against me?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis well, ladies; why a pox do you look at me, this was your subtle plot; a pox on your clarks wit; you said the jest would beget a comedy when 'twas known, and so I believe 'twill.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Madam, I find you have discovered our design, whose chief end was, to prevent this mischief which I doubt not, but you'll both live to repent your share of, before you have done travelling to the Epsams, Bourbon's, and the spawes, to cure those travelled diseases these knights errant have, with curiosity, sought out for you; 'tis true, th' are mischiefs that dwell in pleasant countries, yet those roses have their thorns; and I doubt not, but these gentlemen's wit may sting as well as please, sometime; and you may find it harder to satisfy their travailed experience, than to have suffered our homebred ignorance.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Hark, if he be not fallen into a fit of his cousin; these names of places he has stolen out of her receipt-book; amongst all whose diseases, find me any so dangerous, troublesome or incurable, as a fool, a lean, pale, sighing, coughing fool, that's rich and poor both, being born to an estate, without a mind or heart capable to use it, of a nature so miserable he grudges himself meat; nay, they say, he eats his meals twice, a fellow whose breath smells of yesterdays dinner, and stinks as if he had eat all our suppers over again; I would advise you Mr. sad to sleep with your mouth open, to air it, or get the brewer to tun it; faugh, an empty justice, that stinks of the lees and casks, and belches Littleton and Ployden's cases; dost thou think any woman that has wit, or honour, would kiss that bunghole; by this light, his head and belly look as blew and lank as French rabbits, or stale poultry; alas, sir, my lady would have a husband to rejoice with, no green-tailed lecturer, to stand sentry at his bed's side, while his nasty soul scours through him, sneaking out at the back door. — these, sir, are diseases which neither the spa, or bath, can cure your garters and willow are a more certain remedy.

sp.speaker: Constant.
sp.p: Well, sir, I find our plot's betrayed, and we have patience left; 'tis that damned captain has informed.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p:
Yet 'tis one comfort, madam, that you have missed that
man of war, that knight of Finsbury; his dowager, with ale and switches, would ha' bred a ballad.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Faith, sir, you see what a difficulty it is, in this age, for a woman to live honest, though she have a proper man to her husband; therefore it behooves us to consider, who we choose.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: The lady has reason; for being allowed but one, who would choose such weasels as we see daily married, that are all head and tail, crooked, dirty, sold vermin, predestined for cuckolds, painted snails, with houses on their backs, and horns as big as Dutch cows; would any woman marry such? nay, can any woman be honest, that lets such hod-man-dods crawl o'er her virgin breast, and belly, or suffer 'em to leave their slimy paths upon their bodies only for jointures? Out, 'tis mercenary and base; the generous heart has only the laws of nature and kindness in her view; and when she will oblige, friend is all the ties that nature seeks, who can both bear and excuse those kind crimes; and I believe, one as poor as the despised captain, and neglected courtier, may make a woman as happy in a friendship as master sad, who has as many faults as we have debts; one, whose father had no more credit with nature, than ours had with fortune; whose soul wears rags as well as the captain's body.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Nay then, I'll laugh; for I perceive, you're angryer than we; alas, has lost both ventures, wanton, and the widow.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Both, and neither so unlucky as to be thy wife; thy face is hanged with blacks already, we may see the bells toll in thy eyes; a bride and a wedding shirt? A sexton and a winding sheet? A scrivener to draw up jointures? A parson to make thy will, man; by this light he's as chap-fallen as if he had lain under the table all night.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Faith, master sad, he's parlously in the right; never think of marrying in this dull clime, wedlock's a trade you'll never go through with; wives draw-bills upon sight, an't will not be for your credit to protest 'em; rather follow my counsel, and marry la Venetiano for a night and away; a Pistol jointure does it; then 'tis but repenting in the morning, and leave your woman, and the sin both, i'th bed; but if you play the fool, like your friends, and marry in serious earnest, you may repent it too, as they do; but where's the remedy?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: What was't you said, sir, do you repent?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By this hand, widow, I don't know; but we have pursued a jest a great way. Parson, are you sure we're married.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Yes, I warrant you, for their escaping.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Their escaping? fool, thou mistakest me, there's no fear of that; but I would fain know, if there be no way for me to get out of this noose; no hole to hide a man's head in from this wedlock?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Not any, but what I presume she'll show you anon.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
Hum! Now do I feel all my fears flowing in upon me; wanton and mistress pleasant both grow dangerously handsome, a thousand graces in each, I never observed before, now, just now,
when I must not taste, I begin to long for some of their plums.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Is this serious, sir?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes truly, widow, sadly serious; is there no way to get three or four mouthfuls of kisses from the parson's wife?

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: This is sad, sir, upon my wedding day, to despise me, for such a common thing.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: As sad, as I could wish; this is a jest makes me laugh. — common? no madam, that's two bitter, she's forest only, where the royal chase is as free as fair.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Were not you a widow today?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Yes faith, girl, and as foolish a one as ever coach jumbled out of joint.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: Stay then till tomorrow, and tell me the difference betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: I hope, thou'lt prove a she-prophet; could I live to see thee turn honest wife, and she the wanton widow.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: I cannot but laugh, to see how easy it is, to lose or win the opinion of the world; a little custom heals all, or else what's the difference betwixt a married widow and one of us? can any woman be pure, or worth the serious sighing of a generous heart, that has had above one hand laid upon her? is there place to write above one lovers name, with honour, in her heart; 'tis indeed for one a royal palace; but if it admits of more, an hospital, or an inn, at best, as well as ours; only off from the road, and less frequented.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Shrewdly urged.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: And though the sins of my family threw me into want, and made me subject to the treachery of that broken faith, to whose perjury I owe all my crimes, yet still I can distinguish betwixt that folly and this honour, which must tell you; he or she that would be thought twice so, was never once a lover.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Parson, thou art fitted; a whore, and apothegms! what sport will she make us under a tree, with a salad, and sayings, in the summer?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, wanton, no fury; you see my aunt's angry.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: So am I, sir, and yet can calmly reason this truth; married widows, though chaste to the law and custom, yet their second Hymens make that which was but dying in the first husband's bed, a stain in the second sheets, where all their kindness and repeated embraces want their value, because they're sullied and have lost their lustre.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: By this light, I'll go to school to wanton, she has opened my eyes, and I begin to believe I have scaped miraculously; by this hand, wench, I was within an inch of being married to this danger; for what can we call these second submissions, but a tolerated lawful mercenariness, which though it be a rude and harsh expression, yet your carriage deserves it.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Fie, master sad, pray leave being witty; I fear, 'tis a mortal sin, to begin in the fifth act of your days upon an old subject too, abusing of widows, because they despise you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Alas, niece, let him alone, he may come in, for his share; the parson, that has so oft received 'em, will not refuse him tithes, there, in charity.

sp.speaker: Wanton
sp.p: That, or conveniency, interest, or importunity, may, by your example prevail; but 'tis not fair play, madam, to turn your lover to the common, as you call it, now he's rid lean in your service; take heed, Mr. careless, and warning Mr. sad; you see how fit for the scavenger's team your lady leaves her lovers.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Such a lecture before I had married would ha' made me have considered of this matter. Dost thou hear wanton, let us forgive one another, being married, for that folly has made us guilty alike.

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: And I would fain know the difference betwixt ours, and a wedding crime, which is worst; to let love, youth and good humour betray us to a kindness, or to be gravely seduced by some aunt or uncle, without consideration of the disparity of age, birth, or persons, to lie down before a jointure; ladies, you may flatter yourselves, but the ingenuous part of the world cannot deny, but such minds, had they been born where our faults are not only tolerated but protected, would have listened to the same things, interest counsels thereto.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Parson, what boot betwixt our wives? either come to a price, or draw off your doxy.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Propose, propose, here will be mirth anon.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Yes, yes, propose, while I break it to your lady; madam, you see, here's a proper man to be had, and money to boot — what, dumb?

sp.speaker: Vvant.
sp.p: No, she's only thinking; faith, madam, try 'em both tonight , and choose tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, no more of this; aunt, take my word for your husband, that have had more experience of him then all these; 'tis true, he will long for these girls, as children do for plums; and when has done, make a meal upon cheese; and you must not wonder, nor quarrel at what he says in his humour, but judge him by his actions; and when he is in his fit, and raves most, put him into your bed, and fold him close in your arms, aunt; if he does not rise as kind and as good a husband as he that sings psalms best, hang me; why, you're a fool, aunt; a widow, and dislike a longing bridegroom! I thought you had known better; do you love a spurred horse, rather than a duker, that neighs, and scrapes? I would not say this, but that I know him; let him not go out of your sight, for he's now in season, a ripe mature husband; no delays; if you let him hang longer upon hope his fruit will fall alone.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: You are merry, sir; but if I had known this humour. She kisses Carl. and he kisses her twice

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You'd ha' kissed him first; but being ignorant, let me make you blush; come, a kiss, and all's friends. — how now, sir, again, again, aunt, look to yourself.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Em! By this light, sweet heart, and I thank thee; nay widow, there's no jesting with these things — nay, I am a lion, in myKisses her again.love: aware, puss, if you flatter me, for I shall deceive you.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Since all are cozened, why should I be troubled at my fortune; faith gentlemen, what will you two give me for a wife, betwixt you?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Faith, they're mischiefs dear bought, though a man get 'em for nothing.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I'm almost of his mind; and if other people find no more pleasure in a married life than I, upon my wedding day, I'd pass my time in the piazza, with the mountebank, and let him practise upon my teeth, and draw 'em too ere he persuades the words of matrimony out of my mouth again. Ay, ay, m. constant, you may laugh, you ha' missed a wife; would I were in your case, the world should see how cheerfully I should bear such an affliction.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Jack, I ha' made my peace at home, and by seeing others shipwrecked will avoid the danger, and here resolve, never to sigh again for any woman; they're weeds grow in every hedge; and transplanting of 'em thus to our beds gives certain trouble, seldom pleasure, never profit.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: See where the enemy comes; now if you be wise, arm, and unite against him, as a common foe; he's come from his old lady, designing a reconciliation; the rogue's provident, and would fain have a nest for his age to rest in; buff and feathers do well in the youth and heat of thirty; but in the winter of old age, captain at threescore, lame and lean, may lie with the almanac out of date.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The parson's grown witty, and prophecies upon the strength of bridecake; if I guess aright, thou'lt be hanged; for 'tis a truth, I have been endeavouring to make it appear, her fears were mistaken in me: but I find the witch more implacable than the devil; the waiting-woman is harder to forgive her part, than my lady. Faithful will not be reconciled, the merciless bawd is all fire and sword, no quarter; bless me from an old waiting-woman's wrath; she'll never forgive me the disappointing her of a promise when I was drunk; her lady and she are coming, but in such a fury, I would not have the storm find you in the street; therefore. I counsel you to avoid the boys, and take shelter in the next house.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, let's home, and with all diligence get our dinner, to defend us; and let the porter dispute it at the wicket, till she signs articles of peace.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Agreed. —

div.stage: Careless is kind to the widow; as he goes out, Wild and pleasant go together, jolly and the parson's wife go together.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: See how they pair now, 'tis not threescore year will part 'em now he has tasted a kiss or two.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: Parson, I'll be your brideman.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: 'Tis well, sir, I shall ha' my time too.

sp.speaker: Jolly
sp.p: I by this hand; nay, we'll share fairly.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That's but reason, wanton; and since he grows tame, use him kindly for my sake.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Can any of you digest sponge and arsenic?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Arsenic? what's that?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p:
An Italian salad, which I'll dress for you, by Jove, ere I'll walk in my canonical-coat lined with horn; death, if I suffer this, we shall have that damned courtier pluck on his shoes with the parson's musons; fine i'faith, none but the small Levites brow
to plant your shoeing-horn-feed in? — how now? As he is going off the Capt. stays him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Prithee, Jack, stay, and say something to the gentlemen, by way of epilogue. Thou art a piece of a scurvy poet thyself, prithee oblige the author, and give us a line or two in praise of his play.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I oblige him? hang him and all his friends, and hurt nobody ; yes, I'm likely to speak for him; you see how I ha' been used today betwixt you, I shall find a time to be revenged, let go my cloak; I have a province, within, of mine own to govern, let me go.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Who, thy wife? faith stay, and give them an opportunity; thy pain will be the sooner over: you see 'tis a thing resolved betwixt 'em, and now thou'rt satisfied in the matter, be wise and silent; who knows what good she may do thee another time; I dare say, if she had as many souls in her as she had men, she'd bring thee a cure of herself.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Let me go, or I shall be as troublesome as you are injurious, for all your titles, sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Lend me your cloak then, to appear more decent; you'd not ha' me present epilogue in buff, whoreson dunce, with a red nose.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Sir, my business is praying, not epilogues.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: With that face? By this light, 'tis a scandal to see it flaming so near the altar; thou lookest as if thou'dst cry tope, in the face of the congregation, instead of amen.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: Thou'rt an ass, 'tis proper there, t'has zeal and fervour in't, and burns before the altar like the primitive lamps.

sp.speaker: Captain
